if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the notice.
For the purposes of subsection (7), the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the notice appealed against.
Any relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against a decision of the local housing authority to serve an HMO declaration.
The appeal must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date of the authority’s decision.

intro.p: Such an appeal—

content.p: is to be by way of a re-hearing, but
may be determined having regard to matters of which the authority were unaware.

intro.p: The tribunal may—

content.p: confirm or reverse the decision of the authority, and
if it reverses the decision, revoke the HMO declaration.

intro.p: In this section and section 256 “relevant person”, in relation to an HMO declaration, means any person who, to the knowledge of the local housing authority, is—

content.p: a person having an estate or interest in the building or part of the building concerned (but is not a tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years of less), or
a person managing or having control of that building or part (and not falling within paragraph (a)).

intro.p: For the purposes of this section and section 256, “appropriate tribunal” means—

content.p: in relation to a building in England, the First-tier Tribunal or, where determined by or under Tribunal Procedure Rules, the Upper Tribunal; and
in relation to a building in Wales, a residential property tribunal.

section.heading: Revocation of HMO declarations

content.p: A local housing authority may revoke an HMO declaration served under section 255 at any time if they consider that subsection (2) of that section no longer applies to the building or part of the building in respect of which the declaration was served.

intro.p: The power to revoke an HMO declaration is exercisable by the authority either—

content.p: on an application made by a relevant person, or
on the authority’s own initiative.

intro.p: If, on an application by such a person, the authority decide not to revoke the HMO declaration, they must without delay serve on him a notice informing him of—

content.p: the decision,
the reasons for it and the date on which it was made,
the right to appeal against it under subsection (4), and
the period within which an appeal may be made under that subsection.

A person who applies to a local housing authority for the revocation of an HMO declaration under subsection (1) may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against a decision of the authority to refuse to revoke the notice.
The appeal must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified under subsection (3) as the date on which the decision was made.

intro.p: Such an appeal—

content.p: is to be by way of a re-hearing, but
may be determined having regard to matters of which the authority were unaware.

intro.p: The tribunal may—

content.p: confirm or reverse the decision of the authority, and
if it reverses the decision, revoke the HMO declaration.

section.heading: HMOs: certain converted blocks of flats

intro.p: For the purposes of this section a “converted block of flats” means a building or part of a building which—

content.p: has been converted into, and
consists of,

wrapUp.p: self-contained flats.

intro.p: This section applies to a converted block of flats if—

content.p: building work undertaken in connection with the conversion did not comply with the appropriate building standards and still does not comply with them; and
less than two-thirds of the self-contained flats are owner-occupied.

intro.p: In subsection (2)“appropriate building standards” means—
in the case of a converted block of flats—

content.p: on which building work was completed before 1st June 1992 or which is dealt with by regulation 20 of the Building Regulations 1991 (S.I. 1991/2768), and
which would not have been exempt under those Regulations,

wrapUp.p: building standards equivalent to those imposed, in relation to a building or part of a building to which those Regulations applied, by those Regulations as they had effect on 1st June 1992; and

content.p: in the case of any other converted block of flats, the requirements imposed at the time in relation to it by regulations under section 1 of the Building Act 1984 (c. 55).

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (2) a flat is “owner-occupied” if it is occupied—

content.p: by a person who has a lease of the flat which has been granted for a term of more than 21 years,
by a person who has the freehold estate in the converted block of flats, or
by a member of the household of a person within paragraph (a) or (b).

The fact that this section applies to a converted block of flats (with the result that it is a house in multiple occupation under section 254(1)(e)), does not affect the status of any flat in the block as a house in multiple occupation.
In this section “self-contained flat” has the same meaning as in section 254.

section.heading: HMOs: persons not forming a single household

content.p: This section sets out when persons are to be regarded as not forming a single household for the purposes of section 254.

intro.p: Persons are to be regarded as not forming a single household unless—

content.p: they are all members of the same family, or
their circumstances are circumstances of a description specified for the purposes of this section in regulations made by the appropriate national authority.

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (2)(a) a person is a member of the same family as another person if—

content.p: those persons are married to , or civil partners of, each other or live together as if they were a married couple or civil partners;
one of them is a relative of the other; or
one of them is, or is a relative of, one member of a couple and the other is a relative of the other member of the couple.

intro.p: For those purposes—

content.p: a “couple” means two persons who ... fall within subsection (3)(a);
“relative” means parent, grandparent, child, grandchild, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, nephew, niece or cousin;
a relationship of the half-blood shall be treated as a relationship of the whole blood; and
the stepchild of a person shall be treated as his child.

Regulations under subsection (2)(b) may, in particular, secure that a group of persons are to be regarded as forming a single household only where (as the regulations may require) each member of the group has a prescribed relationship, or at least one of a number of prescribed relationships, to any one or more of the others.
In subsection (5)“prescribed relationship” means any relationship of a description specified in the regulations.

section.heading: HMOs: persons treated as occupying premises as only or main residence

content.p: This section sets out when persons are to be treated for the purposes of section 254 as occupying a building or part of a building as their only or main residence.

intro.p: A person is to be treated as so occupying a building or part of a building if it is occupied by the person—

content.p: as the person’s residence for the purpose of undertaking a full-time course of further or higher education;
as a refuge, or
in any other circumstances which are circumstances of a description specified for the purposes of this section in regulations made by the appropriate national authority.

intro.p: In subsection (2)(b)“refuge” means a building or part of a building managed by a voluntary organisation and used wholly or mainly for the temporary accommodation of persons who have left their homes as a result of—

content.p: physical violence or mental abuse, or
threats of such violence or abuse,

wrapUp.p: from persons who are or were their spouses or civil partners or with whom they are or were co-habiting.

section.heading: HMOs: presumption that sole use condition or significant use condition is met

intro.p: Where a question arises in any proceedings as to whether either of the following is met in respect of a building or part of a building—

content.p: the sole use condition, or
the significant use condition,

wrapUp.p: it shall be presumed, for the purposes of the proceedings, that the condition is met unless the contrary is shown.

intro.p: In this section—
“the sole use condition” means the condition contained in—

content.p: section 254(2)(d) (as it applies for the purposes of the standard test or the self-contained flat test), or
section 254(4)(e),

wrapUp.p: as the case may be; and

content.p: “the significant use condition” means the condition contained in section 255(2) that the occupation of the living accommodation or flat referred to in that provision by persons who do not form a single household constitutes a significant use of that accommodation or flat.

section.heading: Meaning of “appropriate national authority”, “local housing authority” etc.

intro.p: In this Act “the appropriate national authority” means—

content.p: in relation to England, the Secretary of State; and
in relation to Wales, the National Assembly for Wales.

intro.p: In this Act “local housing authority” means, in relation to England—

content.p: a unitary authority;
a district council so far as it is not a unitary authority;
a London borough council;
the Common Council of the City of London (in its capacity as a local authority);
the Sub-Treasurer of the Inner Temple or the Under-Treasurer of the Middle Temple (in his capacity as a local authority); and
the Council of the Isles of Scilly.

intro.p: In subsection (2)“unitary authority” means—

content.p: the council of a county so far as it is the council for an area for which there are no district councils;
the council of any district comprised in an area for which there is no county council.
In this Act “local housing authority” means, in relation to Wales, a county council or a county borough council.
References in this Act to “the local housing authority”, in relation to land, are to the local housing authority in whose district the land is situated.

intro.p: References in this Act to the district of a local housing authority are to the area of the council concerned, that is to say—

content.p: in the case of a unitary authority, the area or district;
in the case of a district council so far as it is not a unitary authority, the district;
in the case of an authority within subsection (2)(c) to (f), the London borough, the City of London, the Inner or Middle Temple or the Isles of Scilly (as the case may be); and
in the case of a Welsh county council or a county borough council, the Welsh county or county borough.
Section 618 of the Housing Act 1985 (c. 68)(committees and members of Common Council of City of London) applies in relation to this Act as it applies in relation to that Act.

intro.p: In this Act “appropriate tribunal” means—

content.p: in relation to premises in England, the First-tier Tribunal or, where determined by or under Tribunal Procedure Rules, the Upper Tribunal; and
in relation to premises in Wales, a residential property tribunal.

section.heading: Meaning of “lease”, “tenancy”, “occupier” and “owner” etc.

content.p: In this Act “lease” and “tenancy” have the same meaning.

intro.p: Both expressions include—

content.p: a sub-lease or sub-tenancy; and
an agreement for a lease or tenancy (or sub-lease or sub-tenancy).

wrapUp.p: And see sections 108 and 117 and paragraphs 3 and 11 of Schedule 7 (which also extend the meaning of references to leases).

content.p: The expressions “lessor” and “lessee” and “landlord” and “tenant” and references to letting, to the grant of a lease or to covenants or terms, are to be construed accordingly.
In this Act “lessee” includes a statutory tenant of the premises; and references to a lease or to a person to whom premises are let are to be construed accordingly.
In this Act any reference to a person who is a tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years or less includes a statutory tenant as well as a tenant under a yearly or other periodic tenancy.

intro.p: In this Act “occupier”, in relation to premises, means a person who—

content.p: occupies the premises as a residence, and
(subject to the context) so occupies them whether as a tenant or other person having an estate or interest in the premises or as a licensee;

wrapUp.p: and related expressions are to be construed accordingly.
This subsection ... has effect subject to any other provision defining “occupier” for any purposes of this Act.

intro.p: In this Act “owner”, in relation to premises—

content.p: means a person (other than a mortgagee not in possession) who is for the time being entitled to dispose of the fee simple of the premises whether in possession or in reversion; and
includes also a person holding or entitled to the rents and profits of the premises under a lease of which the unexpired term exceeds 3 years.
In this Act “person having an estate or interest”, in relation to premises, includes a statutory tenant of the premises.

intro.p: In this Act “licence”, in the context of a licence to occupy premises—

content.p: includes a licence which is not granted for a consideration, but

excludes a licence granted as a temporary expedient to a person who entered the premises as a trespasser (whether or not, before the grant of the licence, another licence to occupy those or other premises had been granted to him);

wrapUp.p: and related expressions are to be construed accordingly.
And see sections 108 and 117 and paragraphs 3 and 11 of Schedule 7 (which also extend the meaning of references to licences).

section.heading: Meaning of “person having control” and “person managing” etc.

content.p: In this Act “person having control”, in relation to premises, means (unless the context otherwise requires) the person who receives the rack-rent of the premises (whether on his own account or as agent or trustee of another person), or who would so receive it if the premises were let at a rack-rent.
In subsection (1)“rack-rent” means a rent which is not less than two-thirds of the full net annual value of the premises.

intro.p: In this Act “person managing” means, in relation to premises, the person who, being an owner or lessee of the premises—
receives (whether directly or through an agent or trustee) rents or other payments from—

content.p: in the case of a house in multiple occupation, persons who are in occupation as tenants or licensees of parts of the premises; and
in the case of a house to which Part 3 applies (see section 79(2)), persons who are in occupation as tenants or licensees of parts of the premises, or of the whole of the premises; or

would so receive those rents or other payments but for having entered into an arrangement (whether in pursuance of a court order or otherwise) with another person who is not an owner or lessee of the premises by virtue of which that other person receives the rents or other payments;

wrapUp.p: and includes, where those rents or other payments are received through another person as agent or trustee, that other person.

content.p: In its application to Part 1, subsection (3) has effect with the omission of paragraph (a)(ii).
References in this Act to any person involved in the management of a house in multiple occupation or a house to which Part 3 applies (see section 79(2)) include references to the person managing it.

section.heading: Calculation of numbers of persons

intro.p: The appropriate national authority may prescribe rules with respect to the calculation of numbers of persons for the purposes of—

content.p: any provision made by or under this Act which is specified in the rules, or
any order or licence made or granted under this Act of any description which is so specified.

intro.p: The rules may provide—

content.p: for persons under a particular age to be disregarded for the purposes of any such calculation;
for persons under a particular age to be treated as constituting a fraction of a person for the purposes of any such calculation.
The rules may be prescribed by order or regulations.

section.heading: Minor and consequential amendments

content.p: Schedule 15 (which contains minor and consequential amendments) has effect.

intro.p: The Secretary of State may by order make such supplementary, incidental or consequential provision as he considers appropriate—

content.p: for the general purposes, or any particular purpose, of this Act; or
in consequence of any provision made by or under this Act or for giving full effect to it.

intro.p: An order under subsection (2) may modify any enactment (including this Act).

content.p: “Enactment” includes an enactment comprised in subordinate legislation (within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978 (c. 30)).

The power conferred by subsection (2) is also exercisable by the National Assembly for Wales in relation to provision dealing with matters with respect to which functions are exercisable by the Assembly.
Nothing in this Act affects the generality of the power conferred by this section.

section.heading: Repeals

content.p: Schedule 16 (which contains repeals) has effect.

section.heading: Devolution: Wales

intro.p: In Schedule 1 to the National Assembly for Wales (Transfer of Functions) Order 1999 (S.I. 1999/672) references to the following Acts are to be treated as references to those Acts as amended by virtue of this Act—

content.p: the Housing Act 1985 (c. 68);
the Housing Act 1988 (c. 50);
the Housing Act 1996 (c. 52).

section.heading: The Isles of Scilly

content.p: This Secretary of State may by order provide that, in its application to the Isles of Scilly, this Act is have effect with such modifications as are specified in the order.
Where a similar power is exercisable under another Act in relation to provisions of that Act which are amended by this Act, the power is exercisable in relation to those provisions as so amended.

section.heading: Expenses

intro.p: There shall be paid out of money provided by Parliament—

content.p: any expenditure incurred by the Secretary of State by virtue of this Act;
any increase attributable to this Act in the sums payable out of money so provided under any other enactment.

section.heading: Short title, commencement and extent

content.p: This Act may be cited as the Housing Act 2004.

intro.p: The following provisions come into force on the day on which this Act is passed—

content.p: any other provision of this Act so far as it confers any power to make an order or regulations which is exercisable by the Secretary of State or the National Assembly for Wales.

wrapUp.p: Subsections (3) to (7) have effect subject to paragraph (b).

intro.p: The following provisions come into force at the end of the period of two months beginning with the day on which this Act is passed—

content.p: Schedule 9,
Schedule 11, except paragraphs 15 and 16, and
Schedule 14.

intro.p: The provisions listed in subsection (5) come into force—

content.p: where they are to come into force in relation only to Wales, on such day as the National Assembly for Wales may by order appoint, and
otherwise, on such day as the Secretary of State may by order appoint.

intro.p: The provisions referred to in subsection (4) are—

content.p: Part 1 (other than sections 2 and 9),
Parts 2 to 4,
Schedule 10,
paragraphs 15 and 16 of Schedule 11, and
Schedules 13, 15 and 16.
Section 228 and Schedule 12 come into force on such day as the National Assembly for Wales may by order appoint.
Different days may be appointed for different purposes or different areas under subsection (4)... or (7).

The Secretary of State may by order make such provision as he considers necessary or expedient for transitory, transitional or saving purposes in connection with the coming into force of any provision of this Act.

The power conferred by subsection (9) is also exercisable by the National Assembly for Wales in relation to provision dealing with matters with respect to which functions are exercisable by the Assembly
Subject to subsections (12) and (13), this Act extends to England and Wales only.
Any amendment or repeal made by this Act has the same extent as the enactment to which it relates, except that any amendment or repeal in—

blockContainer.p: extends to England and Wales only.

content.p: This section extends to the whole of the United Kingdom.

hcontainer.name: schedule
hcontainer.heading: Procedure and appeals relating to improvement notices

part.heading: Service of improvement notices

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Service of improvement notices: premises licensed under Part 2 or 3

intro.p: This paragraph applies where the specified premises in the case of an improvement notice are—

content.p: a dwelling which is licensed under Part 3 of this Act, or
an HMO which is licensed under Part 2 or 3 of this Act.
The local housing authority must serve the notice on the holder of the licence under that Part.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Service of improvement notices: premises which are neither licensed under Part 2 or 3 nor flats

intro.p: This paragraph applies where the specified premises in the case of an improvement notice are—

content.p: a dwelling which is not licensed under Part 3 of this Act, or
an HMO which is not licensed under Part 2 or 3 of this Act,

wrapUp.p: and which (in either case) is not a flat.

intro.p: The local housing authority must serve the notice—

content.p: (in the case of a dwelling) on the person having control of the dwelling;
(in the case of an HMO) either on the person having control of the HMO or on the person managing it.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Service of improvement notices: flats which are not licensed under Part 2 or 3

intro.p: This paragraph applies where any specified premises in the case of an improvement notice are—

content.p: a dwelling which is not licensed under Part 3 of this Act, or
an HMO which is not licensed under Part 2 or 3 of this Act,

wrapUp.p: and which (in either case) is a flat.

intro.p: In the case of dwelling which is a flat, the local housing authority must serve the notice on a person who—

content.p: is an owner of the flat, and
in the authority’s opinion ought to take the action specified in the notice.

intro.p: In the case of an HMO which is a flat, the local housing authority must serve the notice either on a person who—

content.p: is an owner of the flat, and
in the authority’s opinion ought to take the action specified in the notice,

wrapUp.p: or on the person managing the flat.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Service of improvement notices: common parts

intro.p: This paragraph applies where any specified premises in the case of an improvement notice are—

content.p: common parts of a building containing one or more flats; or
any part of such a building which does not consist of residential premises.

intro.p: The local housing authority must serve the notice on a person who—

content.p: is an owner of the specified premises concerned, and
in the authority’s opinion ought to take the action specified in the notice.

For the purposes of this paragraph a person is an owner of any common parts of a building if he is an owner of the building or part of the building concerned, or (in the case of external common parts) of the particular premises in which the common parts are comprised.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Service of copies of improvement notices

intro.p: In addition to serving an improvement notice in accordance with any of paragraphs 1 to 4, the local housing authority must serve a copy of the notice on every other person who, to their knowledge—

content.p: has a relevant interest in any specified premises, or
is an occupier of any such premises.
A “relevant interest” means an interest as freeholder, mortgagee or lessee.

For the purposes of this paragraph a person has a relevant interest in any common parts of a building if he has a relevant interest in the building or part of the building concerned, or (in the case of external common parts) in the particular premises in which the common parts are comprised.
The copies required to be served under sub-paragraph (1) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the notice is served.

part.heading: Service of notices relating to revocation or variation of improvement notices

content.p: This paragraph applies where the local housing authority decide to revoke or vary an improvement notice.

intro.p: The authority must serve—

content.p: a notice under this paragraph, and
copies of that notice,

wrapUp.p: on the persons on whom they would be required under Part 1 of this Schedule to serve an improvement notice and copies of it in respect of the specified premises.

content.p: Sub-paragraph (4) applies if, in so doing, the authority serve a notice under this paragraph on a person who is not the person on whom the improvement notice was served (“the original recipient”).
The authority must serve a copy of the notice under this paragraph on the original recipient unless they consider that it would not be appropriate to do so.
The documents required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

intro.p: A notice under paragraph 6 must set out—

content.p: the authority’s decision to revoke or vary the improvement notice;
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made;

intro.p: if the decision is to vary the notice—

content.p: the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 14(2)).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Notice of refusal to revoke or vary notice

content.p: This paragraph applies where the local housing authority refuse to revoke or vary an improvement notice.

intro.p: The authority must serve—

content.p: a notice under this paragraph, and
copies of that notice,

wrapUp.p: on the persons on whom they would be required to serve an improvement notice and copies of it under Part 1 of this Schedule.

content.p: Sub-paragraph (4) applies if, in so doing, the authority serve a notice under this paragraph on a person who is not the person on whom the improvement notice was served (“the original recipient”).
The authority must serve a copy of the notice under this paragraph on the original recipient unless they consider that it would not be appropriate to do so.
The documents required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

intro.p: A notice under paragraph 8 must set out—

content.p: the authority’s decision not to revoke or vary the improvement notice;
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made;
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule; and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 14(2)).

part.heading: Appeals relating to improvement notices

content.p: The person on whom an improvement notice is served may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against the notice.
Paragraphs 11 and 12 set out two specific grounds on which an appeal may be made under this paragraph, but they do not affect the generality of sub-paragraph (1).

intro.p: An appeal may be made by a person under paragraph 10 on the ground that one or more other persons, as an owner or owners of the specified premises, ought to—

content.p: take the action concerned, or
pay the whole or part of the cost of taking that action.

Where the grounds on which an appeal is made under paragraph 10 consist of or include the ground mentioned in sub-paragraph (1), the appellant must serve a copy of his notice of appeal on the other person or persons concerned.

An appeal may be made by a person under paragraph 10 on the ground that one of the courses of action mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) is the best course of action in relation to the hazard in respect of which the notice was served.

intro.p: The courses of action are—

content.p: making a prohibition order under section 20 or 21 of this Act;
serving a hazard awareness notice under section 28 or 29 of this Act; and
making a demolition order under section 265 of the Housing Act 1985 (c. 68).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Appeal against decision relating to variation or revocation of improvement notice

intro.p: The relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against—

content.p: a decision by the local housing authority to vary an improvement notice, or
a decision by the authority to refuse to revoke or vary an improvement notice.

intro.p: In sub-paragraph (1)“the relevant person” means—

content.p: in relation to a decision within paragraph (a) of that provision, the person on whom the notice was served;
in relation to a decision within paragraph (b) of that provision, the person who applied for the revocation or variation.
Any appeal under paragraph 10 must be made within the period of 21 days beginning with the date on which the improvement notice was served in accordance with Part 1 of this Schedule.
Any appeal under paragraph 13 must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified in the notice under paragraph 6 or 8 as the date on which the decision concerned was made.

the appropriate tribunal may allow an appeal to be made to it after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (1) or (2) if it is satisfied that there is a good reason for the failure to appeal before the end of that period (and for any delay since then in applying for permission to appeal out of time).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Powers of ... tribunal on appeal under paragraph 10

content.p: This paragraph applies to an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 10.

intro.p: The appeal—

content.p: is to be by way of a re-hearing, but
may be determined having regard to matters of which the authority were unaware.
The tribunal may by order confirm, quash or vary the improvement notice.
Paragraphs 16 and 17 make special provision in connection with the grounds of appeal set out in paragraphs 11 and 12.
This paragraph applies where the grounds of appeal consist of or include that set out in paragraph 11.

intro.p: On the hearing of the appeal the tribunal may—

content.p: vary the improvement notice so as to require the action to be taken by any owner mentioned in the notice of appeal in accordance with paragraph 11; or
make such order as it considers appropriate with respect to the payment to be made by any such owner to the appellant or, where the action is taken by the local housing authority, to the authority.

intro.p: In the exercise of its powers under sub-paragraph (2), the tribunal must take into account, as between the appellant and any such owner—

content.p: their relative interests in the premises concerned (considering both the nature of the interests and the rights and obligations arising under or by virtue of them);
their relative responsibility for the state of the premises which gives rise to the need for the taking of the action concerned; and
the relative degree of benefit to be derived from the taking of the action concerned.

Sub-paragraph (5) applies where, by virtue of the exercise of the tribunal’s powers under sub-paragraph (2), a person other than the appellant is required to take the action specified in an improvement notice.

So long as that other person remains an owner of the premises to which the notice relates, he is to be regarded for the purposes of this Part as the person on whom the notice was served (in place of any other person).
This paragraph applies where the grounds of appeal consist of or include that set out in paragraph 12.

When deciding whether one of the courses of action mentioned in paragraph 12(2) is the best course of action in relation to a particular hazard, the tribunal must have regard to any guidance given to the local housing authority under section 9.

intro.p: Sub-paragraph (4) applies where—

content.p: an appeal under paragraph 10 is allowed against an improvement notice in respect of a particular hazard; and
the reason, or one of the reasons, for allowing the appeal is that one of the courses of action mentioned in paragraph 12(2) is the best course of action in relation to that hazard.
The tribunal must, if requested to do so by the appellant or the local housing authority, include in its decision a finding to that effect and identifying the course of action concerned.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Powers of ... tribunal on appeal under paragraph 13

content.p: This paragraph applies to an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 13.
Paragraph 15(2) applies to such an appeal as it applies to an appeal under paragraph 10.
The tribunal may by order confirm, reverse or vary the decision of the local housing authority.
If the appeal is against a decision of the authority to refuse to revoke an improvement notice, the tribunal may make an order revoking the notice as from a date specified in the order.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: “The operative time” for the purposes of section 15(5)

content.p: This paragraph defines “the operative time” for the purposes of section 15(5)(operation of improvement notices).

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 10 against an improvement notice which is not suspended, and a decision on the appeal is given which confirms the notice, “the operative time” is as follows—

content.p: if the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, “the operative time”is the end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, “the operative time”is the time when a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the notice.

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 10 against an improvement notice which is suspended, and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the notice, “the operative time”is as follows—

content.p: the time that would be the operative time under sub-paragraph (2) if the notice were not suspended, or
if later, the time when the suspension ends.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (2) or (3)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the notice, and
references to a decision which confirms the notice are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: “The operative time” for the purposes of section 16(7)

content.p: This paragraph defines “the operative time” for the purposes of section 16(7)(postponement of time when a variation of an improvement notice comes into force).
If no appeal is made under paragraph 13 before the end of the period of 28 days mentioned in paragraph 14(2), “the operative time”is the end of that period.

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 13 before the end of that period and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation, “the operative time”is as follows—

content.p: if the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, “the operative time” is the end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, “the operative time” is the time when a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (3)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the variation, and
references to a decision which confirms the variation are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.

hcontainer.name: schedule
hcontainer.heading: Procedure and appeals relating to prohibition orders

part.heading: Service of copies of prohibition orders

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Service on owners and occupiers of dwelling or HMO which is not a flat

content.p: This paragraph applies to a prohibition order where the specified premises are a dwelling or HMO which is not a flat.

intro.p: The authority must serve copies of the order on every person who, to their knowledge, is—

content.p: an owner or occupier of the whole or part of the specified premises;
authorised to permit persons to occupy the whole or part of those premises; or
a mortgagee of the whole or part of those premises.
The copies required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the order is made.

A copy of the order is to be regarded as having been served on every occupier in accordance with sub-paragraphs (2)(a) and (3) if a copy of the order is fixed to some conspicuous part of the specified premises within the period of seven days mentioned in sub-paragraph (3).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Service on owners and occupiers of building containing flats etc.

content.p: This paragraph applies to a prohibition order where the specified premises consist of or include the whole or any part of a building containing one or more flats or any common parts of such a building.

intro.p: The authority must serve copies of the order on every person who, to their knowledge, is—

content.p: an owner or occupier of the whole or part of the building;
authorised to permit persons to occupy the whole or part of the building; or
a mortgagee of the whole or part of the building.

Where the specified premises consist of or include any external common parts of such a building, the authority must, in addition to complying with sub-paragraph (2), serve copies of the order on every person who, to their knowledge, is an owner or mortgagee of the premises in which the common parts are comprised.
The copies required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) or (3) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the order is made.

A copy of the order is to be regarded as having been served on every occupier in accordance with sub-paragraphs (2)(a) and (4) if a copy of the order is fixed to some conspicuous part of the building within the period of seven days mentioned in sub-paragraph (4).

part.heading: Service of notices relating to revocation or variation of prohibition orders

content.p: This paragraph applies where the local housing authority decide to revoke or vary a prohibition order.

The authority must serve a notice under this paragraph on each of the persons on whom they would be required under Part 1 of this Schedule to serve copies of a prohibition order in respect of the specified premises.
The notices required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

Paragraph 1(4) applies in relation to the service of notices on occupiers in accordance with sub-paragraphs (2) and (3) as it applies in relation to the service on them of copies of a prohibition order in accordance with paragraph 1(2)(a) and (3).

intro.p: A notice under paragraph 3 must set out—

content.p: the authority’s decision to revoke or vary the order;
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made;

intro.p: if the decision is to vary the order—

content.p: the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule; and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 10(2)).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Notice of refusal to revoke or vary order

content.p: This paragraph applies where the local housing authority refuse to revoke or vary a prohibition order.

The authority must serve a notice under this paragraph on each of the persons on whom they would be required under Part 1 of this Schedule to serve copies of a prohibition order in respect of the specified premises.
The notices required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

Paragraph 1(4) applies in relation to the service of notices on occupiers in accordance with sub-paragraphs (2) and (3) as it applies in relation to the service on them of copies of a prohibition order in accordance with paragraph 1(2)(a) and (3).

intro.p: A notice under paragraph 5 must set out—

content.p: the authority’s decision not to revoke or vary the notice;
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made;
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule; and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 10(2)).

part.heading: Appeals relating to prohibition orders

content.p: A relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against a prohibition order.
Paragraph 8 sets out a specific ground on which an appeal may be made under this paragraph, but it does not affect the generality of sub-paragraph (1).

An appeal may be made by a person under paragraph 7 on the ground that one of the courses of action mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) is the best course of action in relation to the hazard in respect of which the order was made.

intro.p: The courses of action are—

content.p: serving an improvement notice under section 11 or 12 of this Act;
serving a hazard awareness notice under section 28 or 29 of this Act;
making a demolition order under section 265 of the Housing Act 1985 (c. 68).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Appeal against decision relating to revocation or variation of prohibition order

intro.p: A relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against—

content.p: a decision by the local housing authority to vary a prohibition order, or
a decision by the authority to refuse to revoke or vary a prohibition order.
Any appeal under paragraph 7 must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified in the prohibition order as the date on which the order was made.
Any appeal under paragraph 9 must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified in the notice under paragraph 3 or 5 as the date on which the decision concerned was made.

The appropriate tribunal may allow an appeal to be made to it after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (1) or (2) if it is satisfied that there is a good reason for the failure to appeal before the end of that period (and for any delay since then in applying for permission to appeal out of time).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Powers of ... tribunal on appeal under paragraph 7

content.p: This paragraph applies to an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 7.

intro.p: The appeal—

content.p: is to be by way of a re-hearing, but
may be determined having regard to matters of which the authority were unaware.
The tribunal may by order confirm, quash or vary the prohibition order.
Paragraph 12 makes special provision in connection with the ground of appeal set out in paragraph 8.
This paragraph applies where the grounds of appeal consist of or include that set out in paragraph 8.

When deciding whether one of the courses of action mentioned in paragraph 8(2) is the best course of action in relation to a particular hazard, the tribunal must have regard to any guidance given to the local housing authority under section 9.

intro.p: Sub-paragraph (4) applies where—

content.p: an appeal under paragraph 7 is allowed against a prohibition order made in respect of a particular hazard; and
the reason, or one of the reasons, for allowing the appeal is that one of the courses of action mentioned in paragraph 8(2) is the best course of action in relation to that hazard.
The tribunal must, if requested to do so by the appellant or the local housing authority, include in its decision a finding to that effect and identifying the course of action concerned.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Powers of ... tribunal on appeal under paragraph 9

content.p: This paragraph applies to an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 9.
Paragraph 11(2) applies to such an appeal as it applies to an appeal under paragraph 7.
The tribunal may by order confirm, reverse or vary the decision of the local housing authority.
If the appeal is against a decision of the authority to refuse to revoke a prohibition order, the tribunal may make an order revoking the prohibition order as from a date specified in its order.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: “The operative time” for the purposes of section 24(5)

content.p: This paragraph defines “the operative time” for the purposes of section 24(5)(operation of prohibition orders).

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 7 against a prohibition order which is not suspended, and a decision on the appeal is given which confirms the order, “the operative time” is as follows—

content.p: if the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, “the operative time” is the end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, “the operative time” is the time when a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the order.

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 7 against a prohibition order which is suspended, and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the order, “the operative time” is as follows—

content.p: the time that would be the operative time under sub-paragraph (2) if the order were not suspended, or
if later, the time when the suspension ends.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (2) or (3)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the notice, and
references to a decision which confirms the order are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: “The operative time” for the purposes of section 25(7)

content.p: This paragraph defines “the operative time” for the purposes of section 25(7)(revocation or variation of prohibition orders).
If no appeal is made under paragraph 9 before the end of the period of 28 days mentioned in paragraph 10(2), “the operative time” is the end of that period.

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 10 within that period and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation, “the operative time” is as follows—

content.p: if the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, “the operative time” is the end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, “the operative time” is the time when a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (3)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the variation, and
references to a decision which confirms the variation are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.

intro.p: In this Part of this Schedule “relevant person”, in relation to a prohibition order, means a person who is—

content.p: an owner or occupier of the whole or part of the specified premises,
authorised to permit persons to occupy the whole or part of those premises, or
a mortgagee of the whole or part of those premises.

If any specified premises are common parts of a building containing one or more flats, then in relation to those specified premises, “relevant person” means every person who is an owner or mortgagee of the premises in which the common parts are comprised.

hcontainer.name: schedule
hcontainer.heading: Improvement notices: enforcement action by local housing authorities

part.heading: Action taken by agreement

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Power to take action by agreement

content.p: The local housing authority may, by agreement with the person on whom an improvement notice has been served, take any action which that person is required to take in relation to any premises in pursuance of the notice.

For that purpose the authority have all the rights which that person would have against any occupying tenant of, and any other person having an interest in, the premises (or any part of the premises).

intro.p: In this paragraph—

content.p: “improvement notice” means an improvement notice which has become operative under Chapter 2 of Part 1 of this Act;

intro.p: “occupying tenant”, in relation to any premises, means a person (other than an owner-occupier) who—

content.p: occupies or is entitled to occupy the premises as a lessee;
is a statutory tenant of the premises;
occupies the premises under a restricted contract;
is a protected occupier within the meaning of the Rent (Agriculture) Act 1976 (c. 80); or
is a licensee under an assured agricultural occupancy;

“owner-occupier”, in relation to any premises, means the person who occupies or is entitled to occupy the premises as owner or lessee under a long tenancy (within the meaning of Part 1 of the Leasehold Reform Act 1967 (c. 88)).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Expenses of taking action by agreement

content.p: Any action taken by the local housing authority under paragraph 1 is to be taken at the expense of the person on whom the notice is served.

part.heading: Power to take action without agreement

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Power to take action without agreement

content.p: The local housing authority may themselves take the action required to be taken in relation to a hazard by an improvement notice if sub-paragraph (2) or (3) applies.
This sub-paragraph applies if the notice is not complied with in relation to that hazard.

This sub-paragraph applies if, before the end of the period which under section 30(2) is appropriate for completion of the action specified in the notice in relation to the hazard, they consider that reasonable progress is not being made towards compliance with the notice in relation to the hazard.

Any person authorised in writing by the authority may enter any part of the specified premises for the purposes of the taking of any action which the authority are authorised to take under this paragraph.
The right of entry conferred by sub-paragraph (4) may be exercised at any reasonable time.

Any reference in this Part of this Schedule (of whatever nature) to a local housing authority entering any premises under this paragraph is a reference to their doing so in accordance with sub-paragraph (4).
In this paragraph “improvement notice” means an improvement notice which has become operative under Chapter 2 of Part 1 of this Act.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Notice requirements in relation to taking action without agreement

content.p: The local housing authority must serve a notice under this paragraph before they enter any premises under paragraph 3 for the purpose of taking action in relation to a hazard.

intro.p: The notice must identify the improvement notice to which it relates and state—

content.p: the premises and hazard concerned;
that the authority intend to enter the premises;
the action which the authority intend to take on the premises; and
the power under which the authority intend to enter the premises and take the action.
The notice must be served on the person on whom the improvement notice was served, and a copy of the notice must be served on any other person who is an occupier of the premises.
The notice and any such copy must be served sufficiently in advance of the time when the authority intend to enter the premises as to give the recipients reasonable notice of the intended entry.
A copy of the notice may also be served on any owner of the premises.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Obstruction of action taken without agreement

intro.p: If, at any relevant time—

content.p: the person on whom the notice under paragraph 4 was served is on the premises for the purpose of carrying out any works, or
any workman employed by that person, or by any contractor employed by that person, is on the premises for such a purpose,

wrapUp.p: that person is to be taken to have committed an offence under section 241(1).

content.p: In proceedings for such an offence it is a defence that there was an urgent necessity to carry out the works in order to prevent danger to persons occupying the premises.

intro.p: In sub-paragraph (1)“relevant time” means any time—

content.p: after the end of the period of 7 days beginning with the date of service of the notice under paragraph 4, and
when any workman or contractor employed by the local housing authority is taking action on the premises which has been mentioned in the notice in accordance with paragraph 4(2)(c).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Expenses in relation to taking action without agreement

content.p: Part 3 of this Schedule applies with respect to the recovery by the local housing authority of expenses incurred by them in taking action under paragraph 3.

Sub-paragraph (3) applies where, after a local housing authority have given notice under paragraph 4 of their intention to enter premises and take action, the action is in fact taken by the person on whom the improvement notice is served.

Any administrative and other expenses incurred by the authority with a view to themselves taking the action are to be treated for the purposes of Part 3 of this Schedule as expenses incurred by them in taking action under paragraph 3.

part.heading: Recovery of certain expenses

content.p: This Part of this Schedule applies for the purpose of enabling a local housing authority to recover expenses reasonably incurred by them in taking action under paragraph 3.
The expenses are recoverable by the local housing authority from the person on whom the improvement notice was served (“the relevant person”).

Where the relevant person receives the rent of the premises as agent or trustee for another person, the expenses are also recoverable by the local housing authority from the other person, or partly from him and partly from the relevant person.

intro.p: Sub-paragraph (4) applies where the relevant person proves in connection with a demand under paragraph 9—

content.p: that sub-paragraph (2) applies, and

that he has not, and since the date of the service on him of the demand has not had, in his hands on behalf of the other person sufficient money to discharge the whole demand of the local housing authority.
The liability of the relevant person is limited to the total amount of the money which he has, or has had, in his hands as mentioned in sub-paragraph (3)(b).

Expenses are not recoverable under this paragraph so far as they are, by any direction given by the appropriate tribunal on an appeal to the tribunal under paragraph 11, recoverable under an order of the tribunal.

A demand for expenses recoverable under paragraph 8, together with interest in accordance with paragraph 10, must be served on each person from whom the local housing authority are seeking to recover them.
If no appeal is brought, the demand becomes operative at the end of the period of 21 days beginning with the date of service of the demand.
A demand which becomes operative under sub-paragraph (2) is final and conclusive as to matters which could have been raised on an appeal.
Paragraph 11 deals with appeals against demands.

Expenses in respect of which a demand is served carry interest, at such reasonable rate as the local housing authority may determine, from the date of service until payment of all sums due under the demand.
A person on whom a demand for the recovery of expenses has been served may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against the demand.
An appeal must be made within the period of 21 days beginning with the date of service of the demand or copy of it under paragraph 9.

The appropriate tribunal may allow an appeal to be made to it after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) if it is satisfied that there is a good reason for the failure to appeal before the end of that period (and for any delay since then in applying for permission to appeal out of time).

Where the demand relates to action taken by virtue of paragraph 3(3), an appeal may be brought on the ground that reasonable progress was being made towards compliance with the improvement notice when the local housing authority gave notice under paragraph 4 of their intention to enter and take the action.
This does not affect the generality of sub-paragraph (1).
The tribunal may, on an appeal, make such order confirming, quashing or varying the demand as it considers appropriate.

intro.p: A demand against which an appeal is brought becomes operative as follows—

content.p: if a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the demand and the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, the demand becomes operative at end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the demand, the demand becomes operative at the time of that decision.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (6)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the demand, and
references to a decision which confirms the demand are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.
No question may be raised on appeal under this paragraph which might have been raised on an appeal against the improvement notice.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Expenses and interest recoverable from occupiers

intro.p: Where a demand becomes operative by virtue of paragraph 9(2) or 11(6), the local housing authority may serve a recovery notice on any person—

content.p: who occupies the premises concerned, or part of those premises, as the tenant or licensee of the person on whom the demand was served under paragraph 9(1); and
who, by virtue of his tenancy or licence, pays rent or any sum in the nature of rent to the person on whom the demand was served.

intro.p: A recovery notice is a notice—

content.p: stating the amount of expenses recoverable by the local housing authority; and

requiring all future payments by the tenant or licensee of rent or sums in the nature of rent (whether already accrued due or not) to be made direct to the authority until the expenses recoverable by the authority, together with any accrued interest on them, have been duly paid.

In the case of a demand which was served on any person as agent or trustee for another person (“the principal”), sub-paragraph (1) has effect as if the references in paragraphs (a) and (b) to the person on whom the demand was served were references to that person or the principal.

The effect of a recovery notice, once served under sub-paragraph (1), is to transfer to the local housing authority the right to recover, receive and give a discharge for the rent or sums in the nature of rent.
This is subject to any direction to the contrary contained in a further notice served by the local housing authority on the tenant or licensee.

In addition, the right to recover, receive and give a discharge for any rent or sums in the nature of rent is postponed to any right in respect of that rent or those sums which may at any time be vested in a superior landlord by virtue of a notice under section 6 of the Law of Distress Amendment Act 1908 (c. 53).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Expenses and interest to be a charge on the premises

content.p: Until recovered, the expenses recoverable by the local housing authority, together with any accrued interest on them, are a charge on the premises to which the improvement notice related.
The charge takes effect when the demand for the expenses and interest becomes operative by virtue of paragraph 9(2) or 11(6).

For the purpose of enforcing the charge, the local housing authority have the same powers and remedies, under the Law of Property Act 1925 (c. 20) and otherwise, as if they were mortgagees by deed having powers of sale and lease, of accepting surrenders of leases and of appointing a receiver.
The power of appointing a receiver is exercisable at any time after the end of one month beginning with the date when the charge takes effect.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Recovery of expenses and interest from other persons profiting from taking of action

intro.p: Sub-paragraph (2) applies if, on an application to the appropriate tribunal, the local housing authority satisfy the tribunal that—

content.p: the expenses and interest have not been and are unlikely to be recovered; and

a person is profiting by the taking of the action under paragraph 3 in respect of which the expenses were incurred in that he is obtaining rents or other payments which would not have been obtainable if the number of persons living in the premises was limited to that appropriate for the premises in their state before the action was taken.
The tribunal may, if satisfied that the person concerned has had proper notice of the application, order him to make such payments to the local housing authority as the tribunal considers to be just.

hcontainer.name: schedule
hcontainer.heading: Licences under Parts 2 and 3: mandatory conditions

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Conditions to be included in licences under Part 2 or 3

content.p: A licence under Part 2 or 3 must include the following conditions.

Conditions requiring the licence holder, if gas is supplied to the house, to produce to the local housing authority annually for their inspection a gas safety certificate obtained in respect of the house within the last 12 months.

intro.p: Conditions requiring the licence holder—

content.p: to keep electrical appliances and furniture made available by him in the house in a safe condition;
to supply the authority, on demand, with a declaration by him as to the safety of such appliances and furniture;

intro.p: where the house is in England, additionally—

content.p: to ensure that every electrical installation in the house is in proper working order and safe for continued use; and
to supply the authority, on demand, with a declaration by him as to the safety of such installations;
for the purposes of paragraph (c) “electrical installation” has the meaning given in regulation 2(1) of the Building Regulations 2010.

intro.p: Conditions requiring the licence holder—
where the house is in England—

content.p: to ensure that a smoke alarm is installed on each storey of the house on which there is a room used wholly or partly as living accommodation, and
to keep each such alarm in proper working order;
where the house is in Wales, to ensure that smoke alarms are installed in the house and to keep them in proper working order;
in either case, to supply the authority, on demand, with a declaration by him as to the condition and positioning of such alarms.

intro.p: Where the house is in England, conditions requiring the licence holder—

content.p: to ensure that a carbon monoxide alarm is installed in any room in the house which is used wholly or partly as living accommodation and contains a fixed combustion appliance other than a gas cooker;
to keep any such alarm in proper working order; and
to supply the authority, on demand, with a declaration by him as to the condition and positioning of any such alarm.
Conditions requiring the licence holder to supply to the occupiers of the house a written statement of the terms on which they occupy it.
In sub-paragraph (4A) “room” includes a hall or landing.
For the purposes of sub-paragraphs (4) and (4A), a bathroom or lavatory is to be treated as a room used as living accommodation.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Additional conditions to be included in licences under Part 2: floor area etc

content.p: Where the HMO is in England, a licence under Part 2 must include the following conditions.

intro.p: Conditions requiring the licence holder—

content.p: to ensure that the floor area of any room in the HMO used as sleeping accommodation by one person aged over 10 years is not less than 6.51 square metres;
to ensure that the floor area of any room in the HMO used as sleeping accommodation by two persons aged over 10 years is not less than 10.22 square metres;
to ensure that the floor area of any room in the HMO used as sleeping accommodation by one person aged under 10 years is not less than 4.64 square metres;
to ensure that any room in the HMO with a floor area of less than 4.64 square metres is not used as sleeping accommodation.

intro.p: Conditions requiring the licence holder to ensure that—

content.p: where any room in the HMO is used as sleeping accommodation by persons aged over 10 years only, it is not used as such by more than the maximum number of persons aged over 10 years specified in the licence;

where any room in the HMO is used as sleeping accommodation by persons aged under 10 years only, it is not used as such by more than the maximum number of persons aged under 10 years specified in the licence;

where any room in the HMO is used as sleeping accommodation by persons aged over 10 years and persons aged under 10 years, it is not used as such by more than the maximum number of persons aged over 10 years specified in the licence and the maximum number of persons aged under 10 years so specified.

intro.p: Conditions which apply if—

content.p: any of the conditions imposed pursuant to sub-paragraph (2) or (3) have been breached in relation to the HMO,
the licence holder has not knowingly permitted the breach, and
the local housing authority have notified the licence holder of the breach,

wrapUp.p: and which require the licence holder to rectify the breach within the specified period.

content.p: In sub-paragraph (4) the specified period means the period, of not more than 18 months beginning with the date of the notification, which is specified in the notification.
Conditions requiring the licence holder to notify the local housing authority of any room in the HMO with a floor area of less than 4.64 square metres.
In this paragraph a reference to a number of persons using a room in an HMO as sleeping accommodation does not include a person doing so as a visitor of an occupier of the HMO.
For the purposes of this paragraph a room is used as sleeping accommodation if it is normally used as a bedroom, whether or not it is also used for other purposes.

Any part of the floor area of a room in relation to which the height of the ceiling is less than 1.5 metres is not to be taken into account in determining the floor area of that room for the purposes of this paragraph.

intro.p: This paragraph does not apply to an HMO which is managed by a charity registered under the Charities Act 2011 and which—

content.p: is a night shelter, or
consists of temporary accommodation for persons suffering or recovering from drug or alcohol abuse or a mental disorder.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Time for compliance with conditions under paragraph 1A(2) and (3)

content.p: This paragraph applies in relation to an HMO in England in respect of the first licence granted on or after 1st October 2018 in relation to the HMO, regardless of whether a licence was in force in relation to the HMO immediately before that date.

If the local housing authority consider that, at the time the licence is granted, the licence holder is not complying with one or more of the conditions of the licence imposed pursuant to paragraph 1A(2) and (3), the authority must when granting the licence provide the licence holder with a notification specifying the condition or conditions and the period within which the licence holder is required to comply with the condition or conditions.
The period specified in the notification must not exceed 18 months from the date of the notification.

intro.p: Within the period specified in the notification—

content.p: the local housing authority may not revoke the licence for a breach (or repeated breach) of any condition of the licence specified in the notification,
the licence holder does not commit an offence under section 72(3) in respect of any failure to comply with such a condition, and
the local housing authority may not impose a financial penalty under section 249A on the licence holder in respect of such a failure.
Sub-paragraphs (2) to (4) do not apply if, before the licence was granted, the licence holder was convicted of an offence under section 72(2) or (3) in relation to the HMO.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Additional conditions to be included in licences under Part 2: household waste

content.p: Where the HMO is in England, a licence under Part 2 must include conditions requiring the licence holder to comply with any scheme which is provided by the local housing authority to the licence holder and which relates to the storage and disposal of household waste at the HMO pending collection.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Additional conditions to be included in licences under Part 3

content.p: A licence under Part 3 must include conditions requiring the licence holder to demand references from persons who wish to occupy the house.

intro.p: The appropriate national authority may by regulations amend this Schedule so as to alter (by the addition or removal of conditions) the conditions which must be included—

content.p: in a licence under Part 2 or 3, or
only in a licence under one of those Parts.
In this Schedule “the house” means the HMO or Part 3 house in respect of which the licence is granted.

hcontainer.name: schedule
hcontainer.heading: Licences under Parts 2 and 3: procedure and appeals

part.heading: Procedure relating to grant or refusal of licences

intro.p: Before granting a licence, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph, together with a copy of the proposed licence, on the applicant for the licence and each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 1 must state that the authority are proposing to grant the licence and set out—

content.p: the reasons for granting the licence,
the main terms of the licence, and
the end of the consultation period.

This paragraph applies if, having considered representations made in accordance with a notice under paragraph 1 or this paragraph, the local housing authority propose to grant a licence with modifications.

intro.p: Before granting the licence the authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on the applicant for the licence and each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 3 must set out—

content.p: the proposed modifications,
the reasons for them, and
the end of the consultation period.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Requirements before refusal to grant licence

intro.p: Before refusing to grant a licence, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on the applicant for the licence and each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 5 must state that the local housing authority are proposing to refuse to grant the licence and set out—

content.p: the reasons for refusing to grant the licence, and
the end of the consultation period.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Requirements following grant or refusal of licence

content.p: This paragraph applies where the local housing authority decide to grant a licence.

intro.p: The local housing authority must serve on the applicant for the licence (and, if different, the licence holder) and each relevant person—

content.p: a copy of the licence, and

intro.p: a notice setting out—

content.p: the reasons for deciding to grant the licence and the date on which the decision was made,
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 33(1)).
The documents required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority refuse to grant a licence.

intro.p: The local housing authority must serve on the applicant for the licence and each relevant person a notice setting out—

content.p: the authority’s decision not to grant the licence,
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made,
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 33(1)).
The notices required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Exceptions from requirements in relation to grant or refusal of licences

intro.p: The requirements of paragraph 3 (and those of paragraph 1) do not apply if the local housing authority—

content.p: have already served a notice under paragraph 1 but not paragraph 3 in relation to the proposed licence, and
consider that the modifications which are now being proposed are not material in any respect.

intro.p: The requirements of paragraph 3 (and those of paragraph 1) do not apply if the local housing authority—

content.p: have already served notices under paragraphs 1 and 3 in relation to the matter concerned, and
consider that the further modifications which are now being proposed do not differ in any material respect from the modifications in relation to which a notice was last served under paragraph 3.
Paragraphs 5, 6 and 8 do not apply to a refusal to grant a licence on particular terms if the local housing authority are proposing to grant the licence on different terms.
The requirements of paragraph 5 do not apply where the refusal to grant the licence was because of section 66(3C) or 89(3C) (person with banning order not a fit and proper person).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Meaning of “the end of the consultation period”

content.p: In this Part of this Schedule “the end of the consultation period” means the last day for making representations in respect of the matter in question.

intro.p: The end of the consultation period must be—

content.p: in the case of a notice under paragraph 1 or 5, a day which is at least 14 days after the date of service of the notice; and
in the case of a notice under paragraph 3, a day which is at least 7 days after the date of service of the notice.
In sub-paragraph (2)“the date of service”of a notice means, in a case where more than one notice is served, the date on which the last of the notices is served.
In this Part of this Schedule “licence” means a licence under Part 2 or 3 of this Act.

intro.p: In this Part of this Schedule “relevant person”, in relation to a licence under Part 2 or 3 of this Act, means any person (other than a person excluded by sub-paragraph (3))—
who, to the knowledge of the local housing authority concerned, is—

content.p: a person having an estate or interest in the HMO or Part 3 house in question, or
a person managing or having control of that HMO or Part 3 house (and not falling within sub-paragraph (i)), or
on whom any restriction or obligation is or is to be imposed by the licence in accordance with section 67(5) or 90(6).

intro.p: The persons excluded by this sub-paragraph are—

content.p: the applicant for the licence and (if different) the licence holder, and
any tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years or less.

part.heading: Procedure relating to variation or revocation of licences

intro.p: Before varying a licence, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on the licence holder and each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 14 must state that the local housing authority are proposing to make the variation and set out—

content.p: the effect of the variation,
the reasons for the variation, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority decide to vary a licence.

intro.p: The local housing authority must serve on the licence holder and each relevant person—

content.p: a copy of the authority’s decision to vary the licence, and

intro.p: a notice setting out—

content.p: the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made,
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 33(2)).
The documents required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

intro.p: The requirements of paragraph 14 do not apply if—

content.p: the local housing authority consider that the variation is not material, or
the variation is agreed by the licence holder and the local housing authority consider that it would not be appropriate to comply with the requirements of that paragraph.

intro.p: The requirements of paragraph 14 do not apply if the local housing authority—

content.p: have already served a notice under that paragraph in relation to a proposed variation, and
consider that the variation which is now being proposed is not materially different from the previous proposed variation.

intro.p: Before refusing to vary a licence, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on the licence holder and each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 19 must state that the authority are proposing to refuse to vary the licence and set out—

content.p: the reasons for refusing to vary the licence, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority refuse to vary a licence.

intro.p: The authority must serve on the licence holder and each relevant person a notice setting out—

content.p: the authority’s decision not to vary the licence,
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made,
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 33(2)).
The documents required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

intro.p: Before revoking a licence, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice on the licence holder under this paragraph and each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 22 must state that the authority are proposing to revoke the licence and set out—

content.p: the reasons for the revocation, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority decide to revoke a licence.

intro.p: The authority must serve on the licence holder and each relevant person—

content.p: a copy of the authority’s decision to revoke the licence, and
