intro.p: a notice setting out—

content.p: the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made,
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 33(2)).
The documents required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

The requirements of paragraph 22 do not apply if the revocation is agreed by the licence holder and the local housing authority consider that it would not be appropriate to comply with the requirements of that paragraph.
The requirements of paragraph 22 do not apply if the revocation is required by section 70A or 93A (duty to revoke licence in banning order cases).

intro.p: Before refusing to revoke a licence, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on the licence holder and each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 26 must state that the authority are proposing to refuse to revoke the licence and set out—

content.p: the reasons for refusing to revoke the licence, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority refuse to revoke a licence.

intro.p: The authority must serve on the licence holder and each relevant person a notice setting out—

content.p: the authority’s decision not to revoke the licence,
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made,
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 33(2)).
The notices required to be served under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Meaning of “the end of the consultation period”

content.p: In this Part of this Schedule “the end of the consultation period” means the last day on which representations may be made in respect of the matter in question.
That date must be at least 14 days after the date of service of the notice in question.
In sub-paragraph (2)“the date of service”of a notice means, in a case where more than one notice is served, the date on which the last of the notices is served.
In this Part of this Schedule “licence” means a licence under Part 2 or 3 of this Act.

intro.p: In this Part of this Schedule “relevant person”, in relation to a licence under Part 2 or 3 of this Act, means any person (other than a person excluded by sub-paragraph (3))—
who, to the knowledge of the local housing authority concerned, is—

content.p: a person having an estate or interest in the HMO or Part 3 house in question, or
a person managing or having control of that HMO or Part 3 house (and not falling within sub-paragraph (i)), or
on whom any restriction or obligation is or is to be imposed by the licence in accordance with section 67(5) or 90(6).

intro.p: The persons excluded by this sub-paragraph are—

content.p: the licence holder, and
any tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years or less.

part.heading: Appeals against licence decisions

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Right to appeal against refusal or grant of licence

intro.p: The applicant or any relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against a decision by the local housing authority on an application for a licence—

content.p: to refuse to grant the licence, or
to grant the licence.
An appeal under sub-paragraph (1)(b) may, in particular, relate to any of the terms of the licence.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Right to appeal against decision or refusal to vary or revoke licence

intro.p: The licence holder or any relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against a decision by the local housing authority—

content.p: to vary or revoke a licence, or
to refuse to vary or revoke a licence.
But this does not apply to the licence holder in a case where the decision to vary or revoke the licence was made with his agreement.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: No rights of appeal where banning order involved

content.p: The right of appeal under paragraph 31(1)(a) does not apply where a licence is refused because of section 66(3A) or 89(3A) (person with banning order not a fit and proper person).
The right of appeal under paragraph 32(1)(a) does not apply in relation to the revocation of a licence required by section 70A or 93A (duty to revoke licence in banning order cases).

Any appeal under paragraph 31 against a decision to grant, or (as the case may be) to refuse to grant, a licence must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified in the notice under paragraph 7 or 8 as the date on which the decision was made.

Any appeal under paragraph 32 against a decision to vary or revoke, or (as the case may be) to refuse to vary or revoke, a licence must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified in the notice under paragraph 16, 21, 24 or 28 as the date on which the decision was made.

The appropriate tribunal may allow an appeal to be made to it after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (1) or (2) if it is satisfied that there is a good reason for the failure to appeal before the end of that period (and for any delay since then in applying for permission to appeal out of time).
This paragraph applies to appeals to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 31 or 32.

intro.p: An appeal—

content.p: is to be by way of a re-hearing, but
may be determined having regard to matters of which the authority were unaware.
The tribunal may confirm, reverse or vary the decision of the local housing authority.
On an appeal under paragraph 31 the tribunal may direct the authority to grant a licence to the applicant for the licence on such terms as the tribunal may direct.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: “The operative time” for the purposes of section 69(6), 70(8), 92(3) or 93(5)

intro.p: This paragraph defines “the operative time” for the purposes of—

content.p: section 69(6) or 70(8)(variation or revocation of licence under Part 2 of this Act), or
section 92(3) or 93(5)(variation or revocation of licence under Part 3 of this Act).
If the period of 28 days mentioned in paragraph 33(2) has expired without an appeal having been made under paragraph 32, “the operative time”is the end of that period.

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 32 within that period and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation or revocation, “the operative time”is as follows—

content.p: if the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, “the operative time” is the end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, “the operative time” is the time when a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation or revocation.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (3)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision confirming the variation or revocation appealed against; and
references to a decision which confirms a variation are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.
In this Part of this Schedule “licence” means a licence under Part 2 or 3 of this Act.

intro.p: In this Part of this Schedule “relevant person”, in relation to a licence under Part 2 or 3 of this Act, means any person (other than a person excluded by sub-paragraph (3))—
who is—

content.p: a person having an estate or interest in the HMO or Part 3 house concerned, or
a person managing or having control of that HMO or Part 3 house (and not falling within sub-paragraph (i)), or
on whom any restriction or obligation is or is to be imposed by the licence in accordance with section 67(5) or 90(6).

intro.p: The persons excluded by this sub-paragraph are—

content.p: the applicant for the licence and (if different) the licence holder, and
any tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years or less.

part.heading: Procedure relating to making of management orders

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Requirements before making final management order

intro.p: Before making a final management order, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a copy of the proposed order, together with a notice under this paragraph, on each relevant person; and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 1 must state that the authority are proposing to make a final management order and set out—

content.p: the reasons for making the order;
the main terms of the proposed order (including those of the management scheme to be contained in it); and
the end of the consultation period.

This paragraph applies if, having considered representations made in accordance with a notice under paragraph 1 or this paragraph, the local housing authority propose to make a final management order with modifications.

intro.p: Before making the order, the authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on each relevant person; and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 3 must set out—

content.p: the proposed modifications;
the reasons for them; and
the end of the consultation period.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Exceptions from requirements relating to making of final management order

intro.p: The requirements of paragraph 3 (and those of paragraph 1) do not apply if the local housing authority—

content.p: have already served notice under paragraph 1 but not paragraph 3 in relation to the proposed final management order; and
consider that the modifications which are now being proposed are not material in any respect.

intro.p: The requirements of paragraph 3 (and those of paragraph 1) do not apply if the local housing authority—

content.p: have already served notices under paragraphs 1 and 3 in relation to the matter concerned; and
consider that the further modifications which are now being proposed do not differ in any material respect from the modifications in relation to which a notice was last served under paragraph 3.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Requirements following making of interim or final management order

content.p: This paragraph applies where the local housing authority make an interim management order or a final management order.

intro.p: As soon as practicable after the order is made, the authority must serve on the occupiers of the house—

content.p: a copy of the order, and
a notice under this sub-paragraph.
Those documents are to be regarded as having been served on the occupiers if they are fixed to a conspicuous part of the house.

intro.p: The notice under sub-paragraph (2) must set out—

content.p: the reasons for making the order and the date on which it was made,
the general effect of the order, and

the date on which the order is to cease to have effect in accordance with section 105(4), (5) or (7A) or 114(3), (4) or (4A) (or, if applicable, how the date mentioned in section 105(6) is to be determined),

wrapUp.p: and (if it is a final management order) give a general description of the way in which the house is to be managed by the authority in accordance with the management scheme contained in the order.

content.p: The authority must also serve a copy of the order, together with a notice under this sub-paragraph, on each relevant person.

intro.p: The notice under sub-paragraph (5) must comply with sub-paragraph (4) and also contain information about—

content.p: the right of appeal against the order under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which any such appeal may be made (see paragraph 25(2)).
The documents required to be served on each relevant person under sub-paragraph (5) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the order is made.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Meaning of “the end of the consultation period” and “relevant person”

content.p: In this Part of this Schedule “the end of the consultation period” means the last day for making representations in respect of the matter in question.

intro.p: The end of the consultation period must be—

content.p: in the case of a notice under paragraph 1, a day which is at least 14 days after the date of service of the notice; and
in the case of a notice under paragraph 3, a day which is at least 7 days after the date of service of the notice.
In sub-paragraph (2)“the date of service”of a notice means, in a case where more than one notice is served, the date on which the last of the notices is served.

intro.p: In this Part of this Schedule “relevant person” means any person who, to the knowledge of the local housing authority, is—

content.p: a person having an estate or interest in the house or part of it (but who is not a tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years or less), or
any other person who (but for the order) would be a person managing or having control of the house or part of it.

part.heading: Procedure relating to variation or revocation of management orders

intro.p: Before varying an interim or final management order, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 9 must state that the authority are proposing to make the variation and specify—

content.p: the effect of the variation,
the reasons for the variation, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority decide to vary an interim or final management order.

intro.p: The local housing authority must serve on each relevant person—

content.p: a copy of the authority’s decision to vary the order, and

intro.p: a notice setting out—

content.p: the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made,
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule, and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 29(2)).
The documents required to be served on each relevant person under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.
The requirements of paragraph 9 do not apply if the local housing authority consider that the variation is not material.

intro.p: The requirements of paragraph 9 do not apply if the local housing authority—

content.p: have already served a notice under that paragraph in relation to a proposed variation; and
consider that the variation which is now being proposed is not materially different from the previous proposed variation.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Refusal to vary interim or final management order

intro.p: Before refusing to vary an interim or final management order, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 14 must state that the authority are proposing to refuse to make the variation and set out—

content.p: the reasons for refusing to make the variation, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority refuse to vary an interim or final management order.

intro.p: The authority must serve on each relevant person a notice setting out—

content.p: the authority’s decision not to vary the order;
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made;
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule; and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 29(2)).
The notices required to be served on each relevant person under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

intro.p: Before revoking an interim or final management order, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on each relevant person, and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 17 must state that the authority are proposing to revoke the order and specify—

content.p: the reasons for the revocation, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority decide to revoke an interim or final management order.

intro.p: The authority must serve on each relevant person—

content.p: a copy of the authority’s decision to revoke the order; and

intro.p: a notice setting out—

content.p: the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made;
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule; and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 29(2)).
The documents required to be served on each relevant person under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

intro.p: Before refusing to revoke an interim or final management order, the local housing authority must—

content.p: serve a notice under this paragraph on each relevant person; and
consider any representations made in accordance with the notice and not withdrawn.

intro.p: The notice under paragraph 20 must state that the authority are proposing to refuse to revoke the order and set out—

content.p: the reasons for refusing to revoke the order, and
the end of the consultation period.
This paragraph applies where the local housing authority refuse to revoke an interim or final management order.

intro.p: The authority must serve on each relevant person a notice setting out—

content.p: the authority’s decision not to revoke the order;
the reasons for the decision and the date on which it was made;
the right of appeal against the decision under Part 3 of this Schedule; and
the period within which an appeal may be made (see paragraph 29(2)).
The notices required to be served on each relevant person under sub-paragraph (2) must be served within the period of seven days beginning with the day on which the decision is made.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Meaning of “the end of the consultation period” and “relevant person”

content.p: In this Part of this Schedule “the end of the consultation period” means the last day for making representations in respect of the matter in question.
The end of the consultation period must be a day which is at least 14 days after the date of service of the notice.
In sub-paragraph (2)“the date of service”of a notice means, in a case where more than one notice is served, the date on which the last of the notices is served.

intro.p: In this Part of this Schedule “relevant person” means any person who, to the knowledge of the local housing authority, is—

content.p: a person having an estate or interest in the house or part of it (but who is not a tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years or less), or
any other person who (but for the order) would be a person managing or having control of the house or part of it.

part.heading: Appeals against decisions relating to management orders

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Right to appeal against making of order etc.

intro.p: A relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against—

content.p: a decision of the local housing authority to make an interim or final management order, or
the terms of such an order (including, if it is a final management order, those of the management scheme contained in it).

Except to the extent that an appeal may be made in accordance with sub-paragraphs (3) and (4), sub-paragraph (1) does not apply to an interim management order made under section 102(4) or (7) or in accordance with a direction given under paragraph 26(5).

An appeal may be made under sub-paragraph (1)(b) on the grounds that the terms of an interim management order do not provide for one or both of the matters mentioned in section 110(5)(a) and (b)(which relate to payments of surplus rent etc.).

intro.p: Where an appeal is made under sub-paragraph (1)(b) only on those grounds—

content.p: the appeal may be brought at any time while the order is in force (with the result that nothing in sub-paragraph (5) or paragraph 25 applies in relation to the appeal); and

the powers of the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 26 are limited to determining whether the order should be varied by the tribunal so as to include a term providing for the matter or matters in question, and (if so) what provision should be made by the term.

If no appeal is brought against an interim or final management order under this paragraph within the time allowed by paragraph 25 for making such an appeal, the order is final and conclusive as to the matters which could have been raised on appeal.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Time limits for appeals under paragraph 24

content.p: This paragraph applies in relation to an appeal under paragraph 24 in respect of an interim or final management order.
Any such appeal must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified in the notice under paragraph 7(5) as the date on which the order was made.

The appropriate tribunal may allow an appeal to be made to it after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) if it is satisfied that there is a good reason for the failure to appeal before the end of that period (and for any delay since then in applying for permission to appeal out of time).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Powers of ... tribunal on appeal under paragraph 24

content.p: This paragraph applies to an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 24 in respect of an interim or final management order.

intro.p: The appeal—

content.p: is to be by way of a re-hearing, but
may be determined having regard to matters of which the authority were unaware.

intro.p: The tribunal may confirm or vary the order or revoke it —

content.p: (in the case of an interim management order) as from a date specified in the tribunal’s order, or
(in the case of a final management order) as from the date of the tribunal’s order.

intro.p: If —

content.p: the tribunal revokes an interim or final management order,
it appears to the tribunal that, on the revocation of the order, the house will be required to be licensed under Part 2 or 3 of this Act, and
the tribunal does not give a direction under sub-paragraph (5) or (6),

wrapUp.p: the tribunal must direct the local housing authority to grant such a licence to such person and on such terms as the tribunal may direct.

intro.p: An interim management order may not be revoked under this paragraph if—

content.p: the immediate landlord is subject to a banning order under section 16 of the Housing and Planning Act 2016,
there is in force an agreement which, under section 108, has effect as a lease or licence granted by the authority, and
revoking the interim management order specified in the order would cause the immediate landlord to breach the banning order because of the effect of section 130(2)(b).

In a case where sub-paragraph (4A) would otherwise prevent the tribunal from revoking the order with effect from a particular date, the tribunal may require the local housing authority to exercise any power it has to bring an agreement mentioned in that sub-paragraph to an end.

If the tribunal revokes a final management order, the tribunal may direct the local housing authority to make an interim management order in respect of the house or part of it on such terms as the tribunal may direct.
This applies despite section 102(9).

If the tribunal revokes a final management order, the tribunal may direct the local housing authority to serve a temporary exemption notice under section 62 or 86 in respect of the house that comes into force on such date as the tribunal directs.
The revocation of an interimmanagement order by the tribunal does not affect the validity of anything previously done in pursuance of the order.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: “The operative time” for the purposes of section 114(2)

content.p: This paragraph defines “the operative time” for the purposes of section 114(2).
If no appeal is made under paragraph 24 before the end of the period of 28 days mentioned in paragraph 25(2), “the operative time”is the end of that period.

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 24 before the end of that period, and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the order, “the operative time”is as follows—

content.p: if the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, “the operative time” is the end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, “the operative time” is the time when a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the order.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (3)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the order, and
references to a decision which confirms the order are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Right to appeal against decision or refusal to vary or revoke interim management order

intro.p: A relevant person may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against—

content.p: a decision of a local housing authority to vary or revoke an interim or final management order, or
a refusal of a local housing authority to vary or revoke an interim or final management order.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Time limits for appeals under paragraph 28

content.p: This paragraph applies in relation to an appeal under paragraph 28 against a decision to vary or revoke, or (as the case may be) to refuse to vary or revoke, an interim or final management order.

Any such appeal must be made before the end of the period of 28 days beginning with the date specified in the notice under paragraph 11, 16, 19 or 22 as the date on which the decision concerned was made.

The appropriate tribunal may allow an appeal to be made to it after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) if it is satisfied that there is a good reason for the failure to appeal before the end of that period (and for any delay since then in applying for permission to appeal out of time).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Powers of ... tribunal on appeal under paragraph 28

content.p: This paragraph applies to an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 28 against a decision to vary or revoke, or (as the case may be) to refuse to vary or revoke, an interim or final management order.
Paragraph 26(2) applies to such an appeal as it applies to an appeal under paragraph 24.
The tribunal may confirm, reverse or vary the decision of the local housing authority.
If the appeal is against a decision of the authority to refuse to revoke the order, the tribunal may make an order revoking the order as from a date specified in its order.

In a case where subsection (2A) of section 112 or 122 would otherwise prevent the tribunal from revoking the order with effect from a particular date, the tribunal may require the local housing authority to exercise any power it has to bring an agreement mentioned in that subsection to an end.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: “The operative time” for the purposes of section 111(2), 112(2), 121(2) or 122(2)

intro.p: This paragraph defines “the operative time” for the purposes of—

content.p: section 111(2) or 112(2)(variation or revocation of interim management order), or
section 121(2) or 122(2)(variation or revocation of final management order).
If no appeal is made under paragraph 28 before the end of the period of 28 days mentioned in paragraph 29(2), “the operative time”is the end of that period.

intro.p: If an appeal is made under paragraph 28 within that period, and a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation or revocation, “the operative time”is as follows—

content.p: if the period within which an appeal to the Upper Tribunal may be brought expires without such an appeal having been brought, “the operative time” is the end of that period;
if an appeal to the Upper Tribunal is brought, “the operative time” is the time when a decision is given on the appeal which confirms the variation or revocation.

intro.p: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (3)—

content.p: the withdrawal of an appeal has the same effect as a decision which confirms the variation or revocation appealed against; and
references to a decision which confirms a variation are to a decision which confirms it with or without variation.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Right to appeal against decision in respect of compensation payable to third parties

content.p: This paragraph applies where a local housing authority have made a decision under section 128 as to whether compensation should be paid to a third party in respect of any interference with his rights in consequence of an interim or final management order.

intro.p: The third party may appeal to the appropriate tribunal against—

content.p: a decision by the authority not to pay compensation to him, or
a decision of the authority so far as relating to the amount of compensation that should be paid.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Time limits for appeals under paragraph 32

content.p: This paragraph applies in relation to an appeal under paragraph 32 against a decision of a local housing authority not to pay compensation to a third party or as to the amount of compensation to be paid.
Any such appeal must be made within the period of 28 days beginning with the date the authority notifies the third party under section 128(2).

The appropriate tribunal may allow an appeal to be made to it after the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) if it is satisfied that there is good reason for the failure to appeal before the end of that period (and for any delay since then in applying for permission to appeal out of time).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Powers of ... tribunal on appeal under paragraph 32

content.p: This paragraph applies in relation to an appeal under paragraph 32 against a decision of a local housing authority not to pay compensation to a third party or as to the amount of compensation to be paid.

intro.p: The appeal—

content.p: is to be by way of re-hearing, but
may be determined having regard to matters of which the authority were unaware.
The tribunal may confirm, reverse or vary the decision of the local housing authority.

Where the tribunal reverses or varies a decision of the authority in respect of a final management order, it must make an order varying the management scheme contained in the final management order accordingly.

intro.p: In this Part of this Schedule “relevant person” means—

content.p: any person who has an estate or interest in the house or part of it (but is not a tenant under a lease with an unexpired term of 3 years or less), or
any other person who (but for the order) would be a person managing or having control of the house or part of it.

hcontainer.name: schedule
hcontainer.heading: Further provisions regarding empty dwelling management orders

part.heading: Interim EDMOs

content.p: This paragraph deals with the time when an interim EDMO comes into force or ceases to have effect.
The order comes into force when it is made.
The order ceases to have effect at the end of the period of 12 months beginning with the date on which it is made, unless it ceases to have effect at some other time as mentioned below.
If the order provides that it is to cease to have effect on a date falling before the end of that period, it accordingly ceases to have effect on that date.

intro.p: Sub-paragraphs (6) and (7) apply where—

content.p: a final EDMO (“the final EDMO”) has been made under section 136 so as to replace the order (“the interim EDMO”), but
the final EDMO has not come into force because of an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 26 against the making of the final EDMO.

If the date on which the final EDMO comes into force in relation to the dwelling following the disposal of the appeal is later than the date on which the interim EDMO would cease to have effect apart from this sub-paragraph, the interim EDMO continues in force until that later date.

If, on the application of the authority, the tribunal makes an order providing for the interim EDMO to continue in force, pending the disposal of the appeal, until a date later than that on which the interim EDMO would cease to have effect apart from this sub-paragraph, the interim EDMO accordingly continues in force until that later date.

This paragraph has effect subject to paragraphs 6 and 7 (variation or revocation of orders by authority) and to the power of revocation exercisable by a residential property tribunal on an appeal made under paragraph 30.
This paragraph applies while an interim EDMO is in force in relation to a dwelling.
The rights and powers conferred by sub-paragraph (3) are exercisable by the authority in performing their duties under section 135(1) to (3) in respect of the dwelling.

intro.p: The authority—

content.p: have the right to possession of the dwelling (subject to the rights of existing occupiers preserved by paragraph 18(3));
have the right to do (and authorise a manager or other person to do) in relation to the dwelling anything which the relevant proprietor of the dwelling would (but for the order) be entitled to do;

intro.p: may create one or more of the following—

content.p: an interest in the dwelling which, as far as possible, has all the incidents of a leasehold, or
a right in the nature of a licence to occupy part of the dwelling;
may apply to the appropriate tribunal for an order under paragraph 22 determining a lease or licence of the dwelling.

intro.p: But the authority may not under sub-paragraph (3)(c) create any interest or right in the nature of a lease or licence unless—

content.p: consent in writing has been given by the relevant proprietor of the dwelling, and
where the relevant proprietor is a lessee under a lease of the dwelling, the interest or right is created for a term that is less than the term of that lease.

intro.p: The authority—

content.p: do not under this paragraph acquire any estate or interest in the dwelling, and
accordingly are not entitled by virtue of this paragraph to sell, lease, charge or make any other disposition of any such estate or interest.
But, where the relevant proprietor of the dwelling is a lessee under a lease of the dwelling, the authority are to be treated (subject to sub-paragraph (5)(a)) as if they were the lessee instead.

intro.p: Any enactment or rule of law relating to landlords and tenants or leases applies in relation to—

content.p: a lease in relation to which the authority are to be treated as the lessee under sub-paragraph (6), or
a lease to which the authority become a party under paragraph 4(2),

wrapUp.p: as if the authority were the legal owner of the premises (but this is subject to paragraph 4(4) to (6)).

intro.p: None of the following, namely—

content.p: the authority, or
any person authorised under sub-paragraph (3)(b),

wrapUp.p: is liable to any person having an estate or interest in the dwelling for anything done or omitted to be done in the performance (or intended performance) of the authority’s duties under section 135(1) to (3) unless the act or omission is due to negligence of the authority or any such person.

content.p: An interim EDMO which has come into force is a local land charge.
The authority may apply to the Chief Land Registrar for the entry of an appropriate restriction in the register of title in respect of such an order.
In this paragraph “enactment” includes an enactment comprised in subordinate legislation (within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978 (c. 30)).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: General effect of interim EDMOs: leases and licences granted by authority

content.p: This paragraph applies in relation to any interest or right created by the authority under paragraph 2(3)(c).

intro.p: For the purposes of any enactment or rule of law—

content.p: any interest created by the authority under paragraph 2(3)(c)(i) is to be treated as if it were a legal lease, and
any right created by the authority under paragraph 2(3)(c)(ii) is to be treated as if it were a licence to occupy granted by the legal owner of the dwelling,

wrapUp.p: despite the fact that the authority have no legal estate in the dwelling (see paragraph 2(5)(a)).

content.p: Any enactment or rule of law relating to landlords and tenants or leases accordingly applies in relation to any interest created by the authority under paragraph 2(3)(c)(i) as if the authority were the legal owner of the dwelling.

intro.p: References to leases and licences—

content.p: in this Chapter, and
in any other enactment,

wrapUp.p: accordingly include (where the context permits) interests and rights created by the authority under paragraph 2(3)(c).

intro.p: The preceding provisions of this paragraph have effect subject to—

content.p: paragraph 4(4) to (6), and
any provision to the contrary contained in an order made by the appropriate national authority.
In paragraph 2(5)(b) the reference to leasing does not include the creation of interests under paragraph 2(3)(c)(i).

intro.p: In this paragraph—

content.p: “enactment” has the meaning given by paragraph 2(11);
“legal lease” means a term of years absolute (within section 1(1)(b) of the Law of Property Act 1925 (c. 20)).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: General effect of interim EDMOs: relevant proprietor, mortgagees etc.

intro.p: This paragraph applies in relation to—

content.p: the relevant proprietor, and
other persons with an estate or interest in the dwelling,

wrapUp.p: while an interim EDMO is in force in relation to a dwelling.

content.p: Where the relevant proprietor is a lessor or licensor under a lease or licence of the dwelling, the lease or licence has effect while the order is in force as if the local housing authority were substituted in it for the lessor or licensor.

Such a lease continues to have effect, as far as possible, as a lease despite the fact that the rights of the local housing authority, as substituted for the lessor, do not amount to an estate in law in the dwelling.
The provisions mentioned in sub-paragraph (5) do not apply to a lease or licence within sub-paragraph (2).

intro.p: The provisions are—
the provisions which exclude local authority lettings from the Rent Acts, namely—

content.p: sections 14 to 16 of the Rent Act 1977 (c. 42), and
those sections as applied by Schedule 2 to the Rent (Agriculture) Act 1976 (c. 80) and section 5(2) to (4) of that Act; and
section 1(2) of, and paragraph 12 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to, the Housing Act 1988 (c. 50)(which exclude local authority lettings from Part 1 of that Act).

intro.p: Nothing in this Chapter has the result that the authority are to be treated as the legal owner of any premises for the purposes of—

content.p: section 80 of the Housing Act 1985 (c. 68)(the landlord condition for secure tenancies); or
section 124 of the Housing Act 1996 (c. 52)(introductory tenancies).

intro.p: The relevant proprietor of the dwelling—

content.p: is not entitled to receive any rents or other payments made in respect of occupation of the dwelling;
may not exercise any rights or powers with respect to the management of the dwelling; and

intro.p: may not create any of the following—

content.p: any leasehold interest in the dwelling or a part of it (other than a lease of a reversion), or
any licence or other right to occupy it.

However (subject to sub-paragraph (7)(c)) nothing in paragraph 2 or this paragraph affects the ability of a person having an estate or interest in the dwelling to make any disposition of that estate or interest.

intro.p: Nothing in paragraph 2 or this paragraph affects—

content.p: the validity of any mortgage relating to the dwelling or any rights or remedies available to the mortgagee under such a mortgage, or

the validity of any lease of the dwelling under which the relevant proprietor is a lessee, or any superior lease, or (subject to paragraph 2(6)) any rights or remedies available to the lessor under such a lease,

wrapUp.p: except to the extent that any of those rights or remedies would prevent the local housing authority from exercising their power under paragraph 2(3)(c).

content.p: In proceedings for the enforcement of any such rights or remedies the court may make such order as it thinks fit as regards the operation of the interim EDMO (including an order quashing it).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Financial arrangements while order is in force

content.p: This paragraph applies to relevant expenditure of a local housing authority who have made an interim EDMO.

intro.p: “Relevant expenditure” means—

content.p: expenditure incurred by the authority with the consent of the relevant proprietor, or
any other expenditure reasonably incurred by the authority,

wrapUp.p: in connection with performing their duties under section 135(1) to (3) in respect of the dwelling (including any premiums paid for insurance of the premises).

intro.p: Rent or other payments which the authority have collected or recovered, by virtue of this Chapter, from persons occupying or having the right to occupy the dwelling may be used by the authority to meet—

content.p: relevant expenditure, and
any amounts of compensation payable to a third party by virtue of an order under section 134(4) or 138(2) or to a dispossessed landlord or tenant by virtue of an order under paragraph 22(5).

intro.p: The authority must pay to the relevant proprietor—

content.p: any amount of rent or other payments collected or recovered as mentioned in sub-paragraph (3) that remains after deductions to meet relevant expenditure and any amounts of compensation payable as mentioned in that sub-paragraph, and
(where appropriate) interest on that amount at a reasonable rate fixed by the authority,

wrapUp.p: and such payments are to be made at such intervals as the authority consider appropriate.

intro.p: The interim EDMO may provide for—

content.p: the rate of interest which is to apply for the purposes of paragraph (b) of sub-paragraph (4); and
the intervals at which payments are to be made under that sub-paragraph.

wrapUp.p: Paragraph 26(1)(c) enables an appeal to be brought where the order does not provide for both of those matters.

intro.p: The authority must—

content.p: keep full accounts of their income and expenditure in respect of the dwelling; and
afford to the relevant proprietor, and to any other person who has an estate or interest in the dwelling, all reasonable facilities for inspecting, taking copies of and verifying those accounts.

intro.p: The relevant proprietor may apply to the appropriate tribunal for an order—

content.p: declaring that an amount shown in the accounts as expenditure of the authority does not constitute relevant expenditure (see sub-paragraph (2));
requiring the authority to make such financial adjustments (in the accounts and otherwise) as are necessary to reflect the tribunal’s declaration.

intro.p: In this paragraph—

content.p: “dispossessed landlord or tenant” means a person who was a lessor, lessee, licensor or licensee under a lease or licence determined by an order under paragraph 22;
“expenditure” includes administrative costs.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Variation or revocation of interim EDMOs

content.p: The local housing authority may vary an interim EDMO if they consider it appropriate to do so.

A variation does not come into force until such time, if any, as is the operative time for the purposes of this sub-paragraph under paragraph 33 (time when period for appealing expires without an appeal being made or when decision to vary is confirmed on appeal).

intro.p: The power to vary an order under this paragraph is exercisable by the authority either—

content.p: on an application made by a relevant person, or
on the authority’s own initiative.
In this paragraph “relevant person” means any person who has an estate or interest in the dwelling (other than a person who is a tenant under a lease granted under paragraph 2(3)(c)).

intro.p: The local housing authority may revoke an interim EDMO in the following cases—

content.p: where the authority conclude that there are no steps which they could appropriately take for the purpose of securing that the dwelling is occupied (see section 135(4));

intro.p: where the authority are satisfied that—

content.p: the dwelling will either become or continue to be occupied, despite the order being revoked, or
that the dwelling is to be sold;
where a final EDMO has been made by the authority in respect of the dwelling so as to replace the order;
where the authority conclude that it would be appropriate to revoke the order in order to prevent or stop interference with the rights of a third party in consequence of the order; and
where in any other circumstances the authority consider it appropriate to revoke the order.
But, in a case where the dwelling is occupied, the local housing authority may not revoke an interim EDMO under sub-paragraph (1)(b), (d) or (e) unless the relevant proprietor consents.

A revocation does not come into force until such time, if any, as is the operative time for the purposes of this sub-paragraph under paragraph 33 (time when period for appealing expires without an appeal being made or when decision to revoke is confirmed on appeal).

intro.p: The power to revoke an order under this paragraph is exercisable by the authority either—

content.p: on an application made by a relevant person, or
on the authority’s own initiative.

Where a relevant person applies to the authority for the revocation of an order under this paragraph, the authority may refuse to revoke the order unless the relevant proprietor (or some other person) agrees to pay to the authority any deficit such as is mentioned in paragraph 23(4).
In this paragraph “relevant person” means any person who has an estate or interest in the dwelling (other than a person who is a tenant under a lease granted under paragraph 2(3)(c)).
Part 2 of Schedule 6 applies in relation to the variation or revocation of an interim EDMO as it applies in relation to the variation or revocation of an interim management order.

intro.p: But Part 2 of that Schedule so applies as if—

content.p: references to the right of appeal under Part 3 of the Schedule and to paragraph 29(2) were to the right of appeal under Part 4 of this Schedule and to paragraph 31(2) of this Schedule, and

paragraph 23(4) defined “relevant person”as any person who, to the knowledge of the local housing authority, is a person having an estate or interest in the dwelling (other than a person who is a tenant under a lease granted under paragraph 2(3)(c) of this Schedule).

part.heading: Final EDMOs

content.p: This paragraph deals with the time when a final EDMO comes into force or ceases to have effect.

The order does not come into force until such time (if any) as is the operative time for the purposes of this sub-paragraph under paragraph 29 (time when period for appealing expires without an appeal being made or when order is confirmed on appeal).
The order ceases to have effect at the end of the period of 7 years beginning with the date on which it comes into force, unless it ceases to have effect at some other time as mentioned below.
If the order provides that it is to cease to have effect on a date falling before the end of that period, it accordingly ceases to have effect on that date.

intro.p: If—

content.p: the order provides that it is to cease to have effect on a date falling after the end of that period, and
the relevant proprietor of the dwelling has consented to that provision,

wrapUp.p: the order accordingly ceases to have effect on that date.

intro.p: Sub-paragraphs (7) and (8) apply where—

content.p: a new final EDMO (“the new order”) has been made so as to replace the order (“the existing order”), but
the new order has not come into force because of an appeal to the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 26 against the making of that order.

If the date on which the new order comes into force in relation to the dwelling following the disposal of the appeal is later than the date on which the existing order would cease to have effect apart from this sub-paragraph, the existing order continues in force until that later date.

If, on the application of the authority, the tribunal makes an order providing for the existing order to continue in force, pending the disposal of the appeal, until a date later than that on which it would cease to have effect apart from this sub-paragraph, the existing order accordingly continues in force until that later date.

This paragraph has effect subject to paragraphs 15 and 16 (variation or revocation of orders) and to the power of revocation exercisable by the appropriate tribunal on an appeal made under paragraph 26 or 30.
This paragraph applies while a final EDMO is in force in relation to a dwelling.
The rights and powers conferred by sub-paragraph (3) are exercisable by the authority in performing their duties under section 137(1) to (3) in respect of the dwelling.

intro.p: The authority—

content.p: have the right to possession of the dwelling (subject to the rights of existing and other occupiers preserved by paragraph 18(3) and (4));
have the right to do (and authorise a manager or other person to do) in relation to the dwelling anything which the relevant proprietor of the dwelling would (but for the order) be entitled to do;

intro.p: may create one or more of the following—

content.p: an interest in the dwelling which, as far as possible, has all the incidents of a leasehold, or
a right in the nature of a licence to occupy part of the dwelling;
may apply to the appropriate tribunal for an order under paragraph 22 determining a lease or licence of the dwelling.

intro.p: The powers of the authority under sub-paragraph (3)(c) are restricted as follows—
they may not create any interest or right in the nature of a lease or licence—

content.p: which is for a fixed term expiring after the date on which the order is due to expire, or
(subject to paragraph (b)) which is terminable by notice to quit, or an equivalent notice, of more than 4 weeks,

wrapUp.p: unless consent in writing has been given by the relevant proprietor;

content.p: they may create an interest in the nature of an assured shorthold tenancy without any such consent so long as it is created before the beginning of the period of 6 months that ends with the date on which the order is due to expire.

intro.p: The authority—

content.p: do not under this paragraph acquire any estate or interest in the dwelling, and
accordingly are not entitled by virtue of this paragraph to sell, lease, charge or make any other disposition of any such estate or interest.
But, where the relevant proprietor of the dwelling is a lessee under a lease of the dwelling, the authority are to be treated (subject to sub-paragraph (5)(a)) as if they were the lessee instead.

intro.p: Any enactment or rule of law relating to landlords and tenants or leases applies in relation to—

content.p: a lease in relation to which the authority are to be treated as the lessee under sub-paragraph (6), or
a lease to which the authority become a party under paragraph 12(2),

wrapUp.p: as if the authority were the legal owner of the premises (but this is subject to paragraph 12(4) to (6)).

intro.p: None of the following, namely—

content.p: the authority, or
any person authorised under sub-paragraph (3)(b),

wrapUp.p: is liable to any person having an estate or interest in the dwelling for anything done or omitted to be done in the performance (or intended performance) of the authority’s duties under section 137(1) to (3) unless the act or omission is due to negligence of the authority or any such person.

content.p: A final EDMO which has come into force is a local land charge.
The authority may apply to the Chief Land Registrar for the entry of an appropriate restriction in the register in respect of such an order.
In this paragraph “enactment” includes an enactment comprised in subordinate legislation (within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978 (c. 30)).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: General effect of final EDMOs: leases and licences granted by authority

content.p: This paragraph applies in relation to any interest or right created by the authority under paragraph 10(3)(c).

intro.p: For the purposes of any enactment or rule of law—

content.p: any interest created by the authority under paragraph 10(3)(c)(i) is to be treated as if it were a legal lease, and
any right created by the authority under paragraph 10(3)(c)(ii) is to be treated as if it were a licence to occupy granted by the legal owner of the dwelling,

wrapUp.p: despite the fact that the authority have no legal estate in the dwelling (see paragraph 10(5)(a)).

content.p: Any enactment or rule of law relating to landlords and tenants or leases accordingly applies in relation to any interest created by the authority under paragraph 10(3)(c)(i) as if the authority were the legal owner of the dwelling.

intro.p: References to leases and licences—

content.p: in this Chapter, and
in any other enactment,

wrapUp.p: accordingly include (where the context permits) interests and rights created by the authority under paragraph 10(3)(c).

intro.p: The preceding provisions of this paragraph have effect subject to—

content.p: paragraph 12(4) to (6), and
any provision to the contrary contained in an order made by the appropriate national authority.
In paragraph 10(5)(b) the reference to leasing does not include the creation of interests under paragraph 10(3)(c)(i).

intro.p: In this paragraph—

content.p: “enactment” has the meaning given by paragraph 10(11);
“legal lease” means a term of years absolute (within section 1(1)(b) of the Law of Property Act 1925 (c. 20)).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: General effect of final EDMOs: relevant proprietor, mortgagees etc.

intro.p: This paragraph applies in relation to—

content.p: the relevant proprietor, and
other persons with an estate or interest in the dwelling,

wrapUp.p: while a final EDMO is in force in relation to a dwelling.

content.p: Where the relevant proprietor is a lessor or licensor under a lease or licence of the dwelling, the lease or licence has effect while the order is in force as if the local housing authority were substituted in it for the lessor or licensor.

Such a lease continues to have effect, as far as possible, as a lease despite the fact that the rights of the local housing authority, as substituted for the lessor, do not amount to an estate in law in the dwelling.
The provisions mentioned in sub-paragraph (5) do not apply to a lease or licence within sub-paragraph (2).

intro.p: The provisions are—
the provisions which exclude local authority lettings from the Rent Acts, namely—

content.p: sections 14 to 16 of the Rent Act 1977 (c. 42), and
those sections as applied by Schedule 2 to the Rent (Agriculture) Act 1976 (c. 80) and section 5(2) to (4) of that Act; and
section 1(2) of, and paragraph 12 of Part 1 of Schedule 1to, the Housing Act 1988 (c. 50)(which exclude local authority lettings from Part 1 of that Act).

intro.p: Nothing in this Chapter has the result that the authority are to be treated as the legal owner of any premises for the purposes of—

content.p: section 80 of the Housing Act 1985 (c. 68)(the landlord condition for secure tenancies); or
section 124 of the Housing Act 1996 (c. 52)(introductory tenancies).

intro.p: The relevant proprietor of the dwelling—

content.p: is not entitled to receive any rents or other payments made in respect of occupation of the dwelling;
may not exercise any rights or powers with respect to the management of the dwelling; and

intro.p: may not create any of the following—

content.p: any leasehold interest in the dwelling or a part of it (other than a lease of a reversion), or
any licence or other right to occupy it.

However (subject to sub-paragraph (7)(c)) nothing in paragraph 10 or this paragraph affects the ability of a person having an estate or interest in the dwelling to make any disposition of that estate or interest.

intro.p: Nothing in paragraph 10 or this paragraph affects—

content.p: the validity of any mortgage relating to the dwelling or any rights or remedies available to the mortgagee under such a mortgage, or

the validity of any lease of the dwelling under which the relevant proprietor is a lessee, or any superior lease, or (subject to paragraph 10(6)) any rights or remedies available to the lessor under such a lease;

wrapUp.p: except to the extent that any of those rights or remedies would prevent the local housing authority from exercising their power under paragraph 10(3)(c).

content.p: In proceedings for the enforcement of any such rights or remedies the court may make such order as it thinks fit as regards the operation of the final EDMO (including an order quashing it).
A final EDMO must contain a management scheme.
A “management scheme”is a scheme setting out how the local housing authority are to carry out their duties under section 137(1) to (3) as respects the dwelling.

intro.p: The scheme is to contain a plan giving details of the way in which the authority propose to manage the dwelling, which must (in particular) include—

content.p: details of any works that the authority intend to carry out in connection with the dwelling;
an estimate of the capital and other expenditure to be incurred by the authority in respect of the dwelling while the order is in force;
the amount of rent which, in the opinion of the authority, the dwelling might reasonably be expected to fetch on the open market at the time the management scheme is made;
the amount of rent or other payments that the authority will seek to obtain;

the amount of any compensation that is payable to a third party by virtue of a decision of the authority under section 136(4) or 138(3) in respect of any interference in consequence of the final EDMO with the rights of that person;
provision as to the payment of any such compensation and of any compensation payable to a dispossessed landlord or tenant by virtue of an order under paragraph 22(5);

intro.p: where the amount of rent payable to the authority in respect of the dwelling for a period is less than the amount of rent mentioned in paragraph (c) in respect of a period of the same length, provision as to the following—

content.p: the deduction from the difference of relevant expenditure and any amounts of compensation payable to a third party or dispossessed landlord or tenant;
the payment of any remaining amount to the relevant proprietor;
the deduction from time to time of any remaining amount from any amount that the authority are entitled to recover from the proprietor under paragraph 23(5) or (6);

intro.p: provision as to the payment by the authority to the relevant proprietor from time to time of amounts of rent or other payments that remain after the deduction of—

content.p: relevant expenditure, and
any amount of compensation payable to a third party or dispossessed landlord or tenant;

provision as to the manner in which the authority are to pay to the relevant proprietor, on the termination of the final EDMO, the balance of any amounts of rent or other payments that remain after the deduction of relevant expenditure and any amounts of compensation payable to a third party or dispossessed landlord or tenant;
provision as to the manner in which the authority are to pay, on the termination of the final EDMO, any outstanding amount of compensation payable to a third party or dispossessed landlord or tenant.

intro.p: The scheme may also state—

content.p: the authority’s intentions as regards the use of rent or other payments to meet relevant expenditure;
the authority’s intentions as regards the payment to the relevant proprietor (where appropriate) of interest on amounts within sub-paragraph (3)(h) and (i);

intro.p: that paragraph 23(2) or, where the relevant proprietor consents, paragraph 23(3)(c) is not to apply in relation to an interim EDMO or (as the case may be) final EDMO that immediately preceded the final EDMO, and that instead the authority intend to use any balance such as is mentioned in that sub-paragraph to meet—

content.p: relevant expenditure incurred during the currency of that final EDMO, and
any compensation that may become payable to a third party or a dispossessed landlord or tenant;

that paragraph 23(4) to (6) are not to apply in relation to an interim EDMO or, where the relevant proprietor consents, a final EDMO that immediately preceded the final EDMO, and that instead the authority intend to use rent or other payments collected during the currency of that final EDMO to reimburse the authority in respect of any deficit such as is mentioned in paragraph 23(4);

the authority’s intentions as regards the recovery from the relevant proprietor, with or without interest, of any amount of relevant expenditure incurred under a previous interim EDMO or final EDMO that the authority are entitled to recover from the proprietor under paragraph 23(5) or (6).

intro.p: The authority must—

content.p: keep full accounts of their income and expenditure in respect of the dwelling; and
afford to the relevant proprietor, and to any other person who has an estate or interest in the dwelling, all reasonable facilities for inspecting, taking copies of and verifying those accounts.

intro.p: In this paragraph—

content.p: “dispossessed landlord or tenant” means a person who was a lessor, lessee, licensor or licensee under a lease or licence determined by an order under paragraph 22;

intro.p: “relevant expenditure” means—

content.p: expenditure incurred by the authority with the consent of the relevant proprietor, or

any other expenditure reasonably incurred by the authority, in connection with performing their duties under section 135(1) to (3) or 137(1) to (3) in respect of the dwelling (including any reasonable administrative costs and any premiums paid for insurance of the premises);
“rent or other payments” means rent or other payments collected or recovered, by virtue of this Chapter, from persons occupying or having the right to occupy the dwelling.

In any provision of this Chapter relating to varying, revoking or appealing against decisions relating to a final EDMO, any reference to such an order includes (where the context permits) a reference to the management scheme contained in it.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Application to residential property tribunal in respect of breach of management scheme

content.p: An affected person may apply to the appropriate tribunal for an order requiring the local housing authority to manage a dwelling in accordance with the management scheme contained in a final EDMO made in respect of the dwelling.

intro.p: On such an application the tribunal may, if it considers it appropriate to do so, make an order—

content.p: requiring the authority to manage the dwelling in accordance with the management scheme, or
revoking the final EDMO as from a date specified in the tribunal’s order.

intro.p: An order under sub-paragraph (2) may—

content.p: set out the steps which the authority are to take to manage the dwelling in accordance with the management scheme,
include provision varying the final EDMO, and
require the payment of money to an affected person by way of damages.

intro.p: In this paragraph “affected person” means—

content.p: the relevant proprietor, and

any third party to whom compensation is payable by virtue of an order under section 134(4) or 138(2) or a decision of the authority under section 136(4) or 138(3) or who was a lessor, lessee, licensor or licensee under a lease or licence determined by an order of the appropriate tribunal under paragraph 22 and to whom compensation is payable by virtue of an order under sub-paragraph (5) of that paragraph.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Variation or revocation of final EDMOs

content.p: The local housing authority may vary a final EDMO if they consider it appropriate to do so.

A variation does not come into force until such time, if any, as is the operative time for the purposes of this sub-paragraph under paragraph 33 (time when period for appealing expires without an appeal being made or when decision to vary is confirmed on appeal).

intro.p: The power to vary an order under this paragraph is exercisable by the authority either—

content.p: on an application made by a relevant person, or
on the authority’s own initiative.
In this paragraph “relevant person” means any person who has an estate or interest in the dwelling (other than a person who is a tenant under a lease granted under paragraph 2(3)(c) or 10(3)(c)).

intro.p: The local housing authority may revoke a final EDMO in the following cases—

content.p: where the authority conclude that there are no steps which they could appropriately take as mentioned in section 137(4)(b) or that keeping the order in force is not necessary as mentioned in section 137(4)(c);

intro.p: where the authority are satisfied that—

content.p: the dwelling will either become or continue to be occupied, despite the order being revoked, or
that the dwelling is to be sold;
where a further final EDMO has been made by the authority in respect of the dwelling so as to replace the order;
where the authority conclude that it would be appropriate to revoke the order in order to prevent or stop interference with the rights of a third party in consequence of the order; and
where in any other circumstances the authority consider it appropriate to revoke the order.
But, in a case where the dwelling is occupied, the local housing authority may not revoke a final EDMO under sub-paragraph (1)(b), (d) or (e) unless the relevant proprietor consents.

A revocation does not come into force until such time, if any, as is the operative time for the purposes of this sub-paragraph under paragraph 33 (time when period for appealing expires without an appeal being made or when decision to revoke is confirmed on appeal).

intro.p: The power to revoke an order under this paragraph is exercisable by the authority either—

content.p: on an application made by a relevant person, or
on the authority’s own initiative.

Where a relevant person applies to the authority for the revocation of an order under this paragraph, the authority may refuse to revoke the order unless the relevant proprietor (or some other person) agrees to pay to the authority any deficit such as is mentioned in paragraph 23(4).
In this paragraph “relevant person” means any person who has an estate or interest in the dwelling (other than a person who is a tenant under a lease granted under paragraph 2(3)(c) or 10(3)(c)).
Part 2 of Schedule 6 applies in relation to the variation or revocation of a final EDMO as it applies in relation to the variation or revocation of a final management order.

intro.p: But Part 2 of that Schedule so applies as if—

content.p: references to the right of appeal under Part 3 of the Schedule and to paragraph 29(2) were to the right of appeal under Part 4 of this Schedule and to paragraph 31(2) of this Schedule, and

paragraph 23(4) defined “relevant person”as any person who, to the knowledge of the local housing authority, is a person having an estate or interest in the dwelling (other than a person who is a tenant under a lease granted under paragraph 2(3)(c) or 10(3)(c) of this Schedule).

part.heading: Interim and final EDMOs: general provisions (other than provisions relating to appeals)

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Effect of EDMOs: persons occupying or having a right to occupy the dwelling

content.p: This paragraph applies to existing and new occupiers of a dwelling in relation to which an interim EDMO or final EDMO is in force.

intro.p: In this paragraph—
“existing occupier” means a person other than the relevant proprietor who, at the time when the order comes into force—

content.p: has the right to occupy the dwelling, but
is not a new occupier within sub-paragraph (4);
“new occupier” means a person who, at a time when the order is in force, is occupying the dwelling under a lease or licence granted under paragraph 2(3)(c) or 10(3)(c).

Paragraphs 2 and 10 do not affect the rights or liabilities of an existing occupier under a lease or licence (whether in writing or not) under which he has the right to occupy the dwelling at the commencement date.
Paragraph 10 does not affect the rights and liabilities of a new occupier who, in the case of a final EDMO, is occupying the dwelling at the time when the order comes into force.
The provisions mentioned in sub-paragraph (6) do not apply to a lease or agreement under which a new occupier has the right to occupy or is occupying the dwelling.

intro.p: The provisions are—
the provisions which exclude local authority lettings from the Rent Acts, namely—

content.p: sections 14 to 16 of the Rent Act 1977 (c. 42), and
those sections as applied by Schedule 2 to the Rent (Agriculture) Act 1976 (c. 80) and section 5(2) to (4) of that Act; and
section 1(2) of, andparagraph 12 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to, the Housing Act 1988 (c. 50)(which exclude local authority lettings from Part 1 of that Act).

intro.p: If, immediately before the coming into force of an interim EDMO or final EDMO, an existing occupier had the right to occupy the dwelling under—

content.p: a protected or statutory tenancy within the meaning of the Rent Act 1977,
a protected or statutory tenancy within the meaning of the Rent (Agriculture) Act 1976, or
an assured tenancy or assured agricultural occupancy within the meaning of Part 1 of the Housing Act 1988,

wrapUp.p: nothing in this Chapter (except an order under paragraph 22 determining a lease or licence) prevents the continuance of that tenancy or occupancy or affects the continued operation of any of those Acts in relation to the tenancy or occupancy after the coming into force of the order.

content.p: In this paragraph “the commencement date” means the date on which the order came into force (or, if that order was preceded by one or more orders under this Chapter, the date when the first order came into force).

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Effect of EDMOs: agreements and legal proceedings

content.p: An agreement or instrument within sub-paragraph (2) has effect, while an interim EDMO or final EDMO is in force, as if any rights or liabilities of the relevant proprietor under the agreement or instrument were instead rights or liabilities of the local housing authority.

intro.p: An agreement or instrument is within this sub-paragraph if—

content.p: it is effective on the commencement date,
one of the parties to it is the relevant proprietor of the dwelling,
it relates to the dwelling, whether in connection with any management activities with respect to it, or otherwise,
it is specified for the purposes of this sub-paragraph in the order or falls within a description of agreements or instruments so specified, and
the authority serve a notice in writing on all the parties to it stating that sub-paragraph (1) is to apply to it.

intro.p: An agreement or instrument is not within sub-paragraph (2) if—

content.p: it is a lease or licence within paragraph 2(6) or 10(6), or
it relates to any disposition by the relevant proprietor which is not precluded by paragraph 4(7) or 12(7).

Proceedings in respect of any cause of action within sub-paragraph (5) may, while an interim EDMO or final EDMO is in force, be instituted or continued by or against the local housing authority instead of by or against the relevant proprietor.

intro.p: A cause of action is within this sub-paragraph if—

content.p: it is a cause of action (of any nature) which accrued to or against the relevant proprietor of the dwelling before the commencement date,
it relates to the dwelling as mentioned in sub-paragraph (2)(c),
it is specified for the purposes of this sub-paragraph in the order or falls within a description of causes of action so specified, and
the authority serve a notice in writing on all interested parties stating that sub-paragraph (4) is to apply to it.

If, by virtue of this paragraph, the authority become subject to any liability to pay damages in respect of anything done (or omitted to be done) before the commencement date by or on behalf of the relevant proprietor of the dwelling, the relevant proprietor is liable to reimburse to the authority an amount equal to the amount of damages paid by them.

intro.p: In this paragraph—

content.p: “agreement” includes arrangement;
“the commencement date” means the date on which the order comes into force (or, if that order was preceded by one or more orders under this Chapter, the date when the first order came into force);
“management activities” includes repair, maintenance, improvement and insurance.
Sub-paragraph (2) applies where, on the date on which an interim EDMO or final EDMO comes into force, there is furniture owned by the relevant proprietor in the dwelling.

Subject to sub-paragraphs (3) and (4), the right to possession of the furniture against all persons vests in the local housing authority on that date and remains vested in the authority while the order is in force.

The right of the local housing authority under sub-paragraph (2) to possession of the furniture is subject to the rights of any person who, on the date on which the interim EDMO or final EDMO comes into force, has the right to possession of the dwelling.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: the local housing authority have the right to possession of the furniture under sub-paragraph (2), and
they have not granted a right to possession of the furniture to any other person,

wrapUp.p: they must, on a request by the relevant proprietor, give up possession of the furniture to him.

content.p: The local housing authority may renounce the right to possession of the furniture conferred by sub-paragraph (2) by serving notice on the relevant proprietor not less than two weeks before the renunciation is to have effect.
Where the local housing authority renounce the right to possession of the furniture under sub-paragraph (5), they must make appropriate arrangements for storage of the furniture at their own cost.
In this paragraph “furniture” includes fittings and other articles.
The local housing authority may supply the dwelling to which an interim EDMO or final EDMO relates with such furniture as they consider to be required.

For the purposes of paragraph 5 or paragraph 13, any expenditure incurred by the authority under this paragraph constitutes expenditure incurred by the authority in connection with performing their duties under section 135(1) to (3) or 137(1) to (3).
In this paragraph “furniture” includes fittings and other articles.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Power of a ... tribunal to determine certain leases and licences

intro.p: The appropriate tribunal may make an order determining a lease or licence to which this paragraph applies if—

content.p: the case falls within sub-paragraph (3) or (4), and

the tribunal are satisfied that the dwelling is not being occupied and that the local housing authority need to have the right to possession of the dwelling in order to secure that the dwelling becomes occupied.

intro.p: This paragraph applies to the following leases and licences of a dwelling—

content.p: a lease of the dwelling in respect of which the relevant proprietor is the lessor,
a sub-lease of any such lease, and
a licence of the dwelling.

intro.p: A case falls within this sub-paragraph if—

content.p: an interim or final EDMO is in force in respect of the dwelling, and
the local housing authority have applied under paragraph 2(3)(d) or 10(3)(d) for an order determining the lease or licence.

intro.p: A case falls within this sub-paragraph if—

content.p: the local housing authority have applied to the residential property tribunal under section 133 for an order authorising them to make an interim EDMO in respect of the dwelling and an order determining the lease or licence, and
the appropriate tribunal has decided to authorise the authority to make an interim EDMO in respect of the dwelling.

An order under this paragraph may include provision requiring the local housing authority to pay such amount or amounts to one or more of the lessor, lessee, licensor or licensee by way of compensation in respect of the determination of the lease or licence as the tribunal determines.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: a final EDMO is in force in respect of a dwelling, and

the tribunal makes an order requiring the local housing authority to pay an amount of compensation to a lessor, lessee, licensor or licensee in respect of the determination of a lease or licence of the dwelling,

wrapUp.p: the tribunal must make an order varying the management scheme contained in the final EDMO so as to make provision as to the payment of that compensation.

content.p: This paragraph applies where an interim EDMO or final EDMO ceases to have effect for any reason.

intro.p: If, on the termination date for an interim EDMO, the total amount of rent or other payments collected or recovered as mentioned in paragraph 5(3) exceeds the total amount of—

content.p: the authority’s relevant expenditure, and
any amounts of compensation payable to third parties by virtue of orders under section 134(4) or 138(2) or decisions of the authority under section 136(4) or 138(3),

wrapUp.p: the authority must, as soon as possible after the termination date, pay the balance to the relevant proprietor.

intro.p: If, on the termination date for a final EDMO, any balance is payable to—

content.p: a third party,
a dispossessed landlord or tenant, or
the relevant proprietor,

wrapUp.p: in accordance with the management scheme under paragraph 13, that amount must be paid to that person by the local housing authority in the manner provided by the scheme.

content.p: Sub-paragraphs (5) and (6) apply where, on the termination date for an interim EDMO or final EDMO, the total amount of rent or other payments collected or recovered as mentioned in paragraph 5(3) is less than the total amount of the authority’s relevant expenditure together with any such amounts of compensation as are mentioned in sub-paragraph (2)(b) above.

intro.p: The authority may recover from the relevant proprietor—

content.p: the amount of any relevant expenditure (not exceeding the deficit mentioned in sub-paragraph (4)) which he has agreed in writing to pay either as a condition of revocation of the order or otherwise, and
